Not that I am knowledgeable about marshmallows, but the fluffy vanilla marshmallow drowned in bittersweet chocolate and rich espresso was unbelievable and redefined my concept of mocha and marshmallows.  I just wish it could have been more melted because a layer of colloidal marshmallow infused with mocha would have made the priciness worth it.  The unmelted marshmallow was awkward to eat because it's a huge cube.  Very photogenic (I shamelessly took 4 photos) and abstractly captures the essence of the sinking Titanic but not too practical and I was clueless on how to eat it.  Drink all the mocha first?  Nibble on it?  I ended up stabbing it with a coffee stirrer, which was a beautiful delicious mess and probably gave me a marshmallow mustache.  (One-up hipsterness factor I guess)

Was it worth $7.75?  For that one lifetime experience, yes.  I'll probably be back to try the more affordable butterscotch latte and dark chocolate mocha.  The mocha in the titanic was an intense chocolate paired with some fancy coffee--it makes Starbucks mochas taste like icky hot chocolate.  Besides the luxury titanic, there are complaints about the price because their small is a tiny and their large is a medium.  However, I can assure you that the large has the caffeine equivalent of a large.  Even in the context of my copious coffee consumption during finals week, I had to save the rest of it for the next day.

In case you haven't already noticed, this is definitely not the place to study; it's best for bringing a book or catching up with a friend.  Seating is frustratingly scarce, with only two small tables (though round wooden tables and latte art make excellent Instagrams).  There's also a bench, which doesn't have the best privacy because it's pretty much in the middle of the store.  I would recommend getting your coffee to-go in case your seat gets stolen, and also since I love the paper cups with a slanted signature stamp.

There is my very complex review for this very complex coffee shop.  Do not, I repeat, do not come here expecting to get work done powered by cheap coffee.  Come here if you are looking for something intriguing and less Troublesome than that rude coffee shop down the street ;)
author: Edna C.

description: Super delicious coffee, incredibly cozy and nice atmosphere, and friendly staff. I live in a different city but I still think about this shop because it was so good. My favorite part was the empanadas. I don't even like eggs and I crave these empanadas all the time. When I was in San Francisco I went to this place three days in a row because it was so good. Highly recommend!
author: Onai A.

description:
Cute coffee shop on Irving St.  Great coffee and pastries and would love to come back.  

This place is small and can be cold/drafty at times.
author: Angelica C.

description:
A little KINDA hooked on the butterscotch latte here.. that's what keeps me coming back though!!! 
The baristas here are very friendly, helpful, and patient. It's a cute little coffee shop, you can't really miss all the green. It's a nice place to hangout with friends and catching up as well as getting things done(homework, work, study, online shopping...hehe).

Btw!!! go to the back of the coffee shop, it's super cute and they have things for display from the store next door so guests can look around and buy.
author: Jane N.

description: Coffee was fine, but don't get a cappuccino to go. It came out in a cup the size of a dentist mouthwash Dixie cup. Too expensive for decent coffee and cheap portions.
author: Belle K.

description:
Cappuccino - 3 stars
Space - 4 stars

Loved this place! The space, the setup, the sunlight. Perfect. The baked goods from local bakeries looked very appetizing, and the very limited seating was the downside but also the undeniable charm of Hollow Cafe. Came here with Leslie L. and it was the perfect place for a quick catch up or to sit with a book and people-watch the Irving street crowd.

As for the cappuccino he pulled out of the Rituals coffee, I'd give it 3 stars for the overpowering milk. But if given another chance the barista might do it better, so I would definitely come back with a book next time while waiting for Izakaya Sozai to open for dinner ;)

Tip - the parking meter outside resets every time you add money. Say you have 20 minutes left and you add a quarter, it'll reset the 20 minutes and just give you a quarter worth of time..
author: Maggie G.

description:
Gave this place a few too many opportunities to change my mind -- but after the same bad experience time after time, I've officially decided never to come back. Here's why:

* The barista has such a supremely bad attitude that it's really hard to imagine that he is still employed. You know the one I'm talking about -- the grumpy guy. Really dude, maybe try cracking a smile. It could work wonders for you.

* If you have a kid - don't bother. It is not kid friendly. You will be scorned with dirty looks to within an inch of your life. 

* The drinks are ok but the food is bad and way too expensive. And they really should invest in some covers or sneeze guards or something.

* What's with that whack garbage can? It's tiny -- like the size of a Cambell's Soup can. Newsflash -- Nothing fits in there.
author: Duke A.

description:
I went here because of all the amazing reviews.

However, in my experience, it was fine. We had a latte and a mocha. They were over priced and nothing special, just your average fresh roasted local espresso. They don't seem to do the homemade marshmallows anymore, and the staff wasn't too friendly.
author: Liz F.

description:
What a fantastic find on our serendipitous adventuring day. 

We met friends for dim sum in the morning and had planned to simply return home. The friends we met suggested we head over to the mosaic steps. That led to a hike up the hill and looking down over Irving Street. My hubby expressed a need for coffee so I looked at options in Yelp. Hollow was in the top 5 and I recommended we try it.

It's a small place and so adorable. The staff was friendly. I ordered a Vanilla Bean Latte which was in-credible. It had real vanilla bean inside. The foam was so beautifully artistic I did my best not to disturb it and managed to keep it in tact until the last drops. My daughter had a hot chocolate and she really enjoyed it. All too often hot chocolate is powder in water, yuck! This was rich and chocolatey and she enjoyed it a lot. Hubby got a double espresso and said it was delicious. 

I did not think the drinks were overly priced and their treats seemed reasonably priced as well. I was super tempted to get the Guinness Cupcake or Vanilla bean marshmallow, but it was post-Thanksgiving and I was trying to be good. Next time I won't be! 

If I lived in the area I could see stopping in regularly whether before work or on a lazy afternoon to enjoy a book or knitting with a delicious coffee drink.
author: Andrea R.

description: Unique. I wanted to order everything on the menu! Butterscotch latte was super small and not too sweet. Cookies were moist. Service friendly. The place felt more European than American. Love!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Do you know what I love more than ritual coffee roasters? --being able to pick it up on my way to work and not having to drive to the mission and scavenge for parking! Hollow is in a very convenient location and is not crowded, at ALL. They sell a lot of neat, but EXPENSIVE knick knacks like $19 hand lotion, $20 coffee spoons, etc.. Nonetheless, had a very cute, homey vibe to it. No seats, but like I said, perfect for picking up before work. 

Bf ordered the Americano, like usual, and was pleased..though he's very easily pleased, so I can't say too much about it. But my cortado? SPLENDID! Very smooth and every bit amazing. Yuuuuum (:
author: Vivian C.

description:
Cute little space.
May take a while to get your drink. I think there were two people in front of me and it took me a while to get my order in.

Titanic was $8.25 which is drinking chocolate with a big cube of marshmallow. When you put it into your drink, it looks like an iceberg right? Thus, Titanic II. I thought it was pretty clever. 

Spanish chicken empanada wasn't bad. Could've used more seasoning. But the outside was crispy which I did like.

They also sell pastries.
author: Heejin L.

description:
This is a review purely on the coffee. The service was fantastic, very sweet baristas and no wait. 

I had a cappuccino and it just tasted like warm milk. It literally had barely any coffee taste. Very unusual for a cappuccino. 

My friend had a macchiato. He agreed with me, same problem, just tasted like warm milk. 

Lastly, prices were a bit steep for the quality of coffee. I believe I paid $4+ for my cappuccino?
author: Olga M.

description:
I'm a coffee slut. Like for reals. Ask all my friends and family :)
This is hands down my favorite coffee shop in the city. 

Amazing americanos! 
I always get their soy mochas. Delicious.
Friendly staff who always have smiles on their faces. 

Hollow - so happy to have you in my life!
author: Cicely T.

description:
Taking shelter after an afternoon of Karl's usual dreariness, Hollow offered a wonderful corner to warm up and relax. 

The lattes were on point and the homemade marshmallow, though a bit pricy, was so fluffy! Impossibly delicious. 

As for the empanadas, Hollow offers quite a few options. My boyfriend and I went with the mushroom one as a snack and the saltiness went very well with the sweetness of our lattes. 

The ambience of Hollow is what makes it such a great place. A snug little shop in the Sunset district, it's a great place to read, relax, and sip the afternoon away.
author: Kristi L.

description:
Wonderful hidden gem! Hollow has easily claimed a spot in my trinity of best coffee spaces in the city, joining Sightglass and The Mill. By best coffee spaces, I mean I'll never ask for my cup to-go at any of these three; I'd want to stay a while and soak in the surroundings. Sightglass is large and industrial, The Mill is bright and airy, and Hollow is small, quaint, and cozy. 

Located in what looks to be a multi-level home's garage, Hollow has three tables with two seats for each. Despite the lack of space, the owners have definitely put a lot of thought into using it efficiently. The result is a comforting little getaway reminiscent of fairy tales and hobbits. I was mesmerized by the spread of items for sale, random things adorning the wall, and a menu that is built into a window pane. Every nook and cranny here is so terribly photogenic that I temporarily forgot where I was.

Espresso-based drinks only here, but they do it well and use Ritual beans. For first-timers, I'd suggest trying their specialities, such as a vanilla latte or a butterscotch latte. The butterscotch latte did wonders for my salted caramel-loving taste buds. The ingredients behind the flavoring are all made in-house.

Time seems to move a little slower here, though not in a bad way. The barista wasn't talkative but he skillfully crafted the drinks behind the bar. He saw that I was taking a picture right in front of him and, instead of telling me my drink was done and to take it, he silently walked off and placed it on my table. He really didn't have to, but it was a nice gesture. A great cup of coffee from a teeny coffee shop that doesn't require getting on the freeway...my prayers have been answered.
author: Olivia V.

description:
Warning: I'm going to be ultra petty here. For reasons I'll elaborate on, this review doesn't cover any of the cafe's beverages or food, but rather focuses on the service. I don't wish to blame anyone who works at Hollow, but I had to write this as a caution to not get your hopes high.

When I arrived around noon, there were a few people in front of me, which required some maneuvering to get into line. The narrow space made lining up rather awkward, and I stood between two white people waiting for the one person of color working as a barista to take my order. However, when my turn came, the barista asked who was next and looked instead to the white man after me, who seemed like a regular, and chatted with him. Although I said I was next, neither of them looked my way. At that, I turned on my heel and walked out without ordering. Just another lesson to never give white-dominated spaces a chance.
author: Sam L.

description: It's pretty price here, because the cups are so small. But once in a while I'll splurge on a butterscotch latte. It's very milky which might not be everyone's favorite. However the hint butterscotch is pretty awesome tasting.
author: Monica E.

description: It is a very, very small cafe, but it is very cute to stop by and get a coffee. The baristas were both very kind & personable.
author: L. F.

description:
A surprising fact about prison is the amount of marshmallows you get served. They used in everything! From yams (sweet potatoes to you westerners) to rice krispy treats (generic, however) to the only-tried-once-because-it-almost-caused-a-riot smores night. I appreciated all of these dishes because I had too as they were served a couple times a week on three squares a day, so nutritionally speaking, it was a no brainer to put them into my mouth. 

I was a little dismayed to find out later that most marshmallows are not vegetarian or vegan friendly. I'm neither, but still, I would have been more hesitant about eating them and would have figured out where the ingredients were sourced from before deciding if nutritionally appropriate. 

Well, pro tip, Hollow sells delicious vegan-friendly marshmallows! Apart from the great coffee, I find the marshmallows tips the scales on the establishment from 4 to 5 stars.
author: Jim B.

description:
My friends and I were looking for a coffee shop to chill at and stumbled upon Hollow -super cute and quaint! The outside is painted pea green with "CAFE" spelled out in white lettering on the window. You can't miss it.

SETTING
Inside is warm and cozy, there is only enough room for the 3 small round tables.They have so many unique and unusual trinkets for sale that add a nice 'Alice and Wonderland' touch to the place. Gold animal head salt and pepper shakers, wall mounted bear head bottle openers, old fashioned scissors, custom one-of-a-kind cards, make-your-own-matcha-tea kits, tea infusers, among other tea and coffee utensils. It's a nice place to pick up a gift while grabbing a latte. 

MENU
-Spiced Matcha Green Tea Latte. I was going to order a Chai Tea Latte, (a frequent and favorite order of mine at any tea/coffee shop), when this caught my eye on the menu. Green Matcha is my weakness so I knew I had to order it. It's $3 flat for a size small (tiny cup) but was tasty, creamy, with hints of fine matcha tea. Comes in size large too. I'd order it again, but not all the time - a little on the pricey side.
-Peppermint Rose Tea. Refreshingly light peppermint taste with a very subtle rose. Also $3 for a little pot of tea which was equivalent to about 4 cups of tea. 
-Guinness Beer Cupcake. I thought the cupcake was very sweet and moist - great for you sugar and cake lovers! Credit for the sweetness comes from the frosting. I couldn't really taste the Guinness Beer in it so it was just another cupcake to me.

PROS
-Quaint, cute little coffee shop. The look and feel makes you feel like a real hipster just by sitting inside it.
-Lots of potential birthday gifts to browse around and play with.
-Delicious drinks!!

CONS
-Not great for large groups, parties of 2-3 fit best.
-A little on the pricey side.
author: Grace J.

description: Perfect little place to hang out and have a good cup of coffee. Decent menu, beautiful interior, friendly staff, comfortable environment.
author: Luke K.

description: This place is great! Such a cute setup, both inside and out, and the drinks are delicious. Great service.
author: Tali H.

description:
Love this place.
Nothing bad about it
On a gloomy day - it's a perfect spot to warm you up!
author: Jenny P.

description:
Hollow has got to be one of the most adorable little coffee shops I've been to.  Everything from the little details of their product set up to their cute little stamp on their cups are perfect. The rustic ambiance is something I could easily come back for, but unfortunately the drinks were just so-so.

I got the Spiced Matcha, the bf got the vanilla bean, and the roommate got the butterscotch.  I gotta say, I was super disappointed in my Spice Matcha. I would have to agree with some Yelpers that it literally taste like luke-warm spiced milk. :( I tried the other two drinks and there wasn't anything too special about them either.  I can see why this place is so popular, its cute and quaint, but if there is a next time for me, I'll skip the drinks and go for their empanadas and other goodies instead.
author: Julie Ann B.

description:
I'm always down to explore cute cafe's in the city, and this place was a cozy, quaint spot to sit down and relax with a latte.

Also, the guinness beer cupcake is delicious! :)
author: Angela D.

description:
Super small and cute cafe in SF. I came here because of the raving Yelp reviews and latte variety. There are a few tables to sit at near the entrance and also another room in the back. The outside is very cute and great for Instagram pictures. 

I ordered the large Butterscotch Latte which was around $5.25. While the latte was very good, I didn't really taste any butterscotch in it. My friend also ordered the Spiced Matcha Latte. This was the first time I'd gotten a matcha latte with spice. It tasted like warm apple cider with a matcha aftertaste. The latte definitely had the right amount of matcha in it and was pretty good as well.

I will probably come back again to try some of their other lattes! (maybe vanilla bean)
author: Kelley L.

description: I love the quaint nature of this place. It's definitely a renovated hole-in-the-wall with a modern vibe and some killer decor. It's incredibly small. I wouldn't bring a group of friends here for a study date, but I'd like to come by myself to read a book and get a drink, relaxing and enjoying some personal time. I like that it's off the main road - so you don't hear too much traffic - and you almost feel secluded from the rest of the world for a moment. The coffee is good - definitely above average, but it's not the reason I would come back (but I've heard they make a delicious butterscotch latte I'd be down to try). What gets me to return in the feeling that I discovered a treasure chest in the Sunset that's completely local and charming, embodying San Francisco's legendary coffee experience.
author: Cassandra A.

description:
A quaint and charming little cafe with beautiful woodsy decor. From the Vintage Edison bulbs to the rustic ambiance, Hollow gives off a "kinfolk" kind of vibe. It has now been added to my "must stop by when in SF" list. 
I had their vanilla bean latte and was so impressed with how deliciously satisfying it was. Not too sweet and the little specks of vanilla bean add the perfect texture and flavor to the latte.
It definitely left a lasting impression. Till we meet again.
author: Victoria P.

description:
I came to Hollow after reading this was one of the 10 most recommended coffee places in SF.  Hollow is an adorable little coffee shop on Irving that gives a very warm and inviting atmosphere!  Seating is very limited as there are only three tables inside.  This place also sells cute gifts (e.g. metal straws) and an extensive collection of Tokyo Milk lotions and fragrances for you to sample while waiting for your coffee.

The service is quite slow, so skip coming here if you're in a rush.  Also, the barista seemed less than enthused to be there (-1 star).  He was very unfriendly !  Aside from that, the Artisan dark chocolate mocha and mocha he made was delicious.
author: Candice H.

description:
Looking for a caffeine hit while in Golden Gate Park but don't want all that pesky breathing room associated with the outdoors? Hollow is your coffee shop!

Size is the most notable thing about this hipster-y coffee shop. It's tiny! You can barely pass through the entrance with people at the tables to your right. The ceiling is also low so if you're the claustrophobic type you want to avoid this place like a regional jet.

Dat coffee tho. It's pretty damn tasty! The first time I went here I was much more impressed with the quality and flavor of the match green tea latte I had than I was the second time around. The butterscotch latte is also pretty good and unusual offering.

The bathroom is to be avoided. Keeping with the small theme there isn't much room to maneuver and the soap dispenser wasn't working. Yuck.

I like this place. I will probably be back if I'm in the area. I was a bit let down after my second visit seeing that the coffee wasn't consistently amazing but it was still good.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Cute .. Cozy.. Coffee.. 
Super friendly. Slower at making drinks but the quality and ambiance makes up for a wait. Seating area in the front and back of cafe. 
They sell fantastic desserts / pastries / Empanadas. 
Drinks are relatively inexpensive as well. 
Not so good for big groups. Music in the background. Good for slow sunny Saturday's and a good book.
author: Frances L.

description:
Really nice well kept cafe in inner sunset. 
Their coffee is really good. There is seating in the front and in the room that's in the back. They also sell little cute things and the staff is really nice. The atmosphere is awesome.
author: Yushi C.

description:
This place is TINY! My goodness. There really isn't space for people to be in line. If your in line, your probably within the personal bubble of those sitting at the four tables, which don't really fit as it is. I think they should move one of the tables outside, there is just one to many in that space. 

But the staff was very friendly, the coffee was great they use Ritual coffee. The Brown-butter chocolate Chip Cookie was AMAZING! Oh my goodness. It was still warm and was melt in your mouth fantastic. Sadly it was the last one. I'd go back for that alone. 

This little whole in the wall was quaint. 

We sat and enjoyed our drinks but I think in the future I would grab and go. It is a little uncomfortable to be sitting while there is such a limited amount of space for people to stand in line.. just awkward. 

If your in the neighborhood, yes try this place, but maybe not if you want to sit and stay awhile.
author: Sara P.

description:
My first visit at Hollow was definitely memorable. It was about 30 minutes before they closed, the lady didn't looked annoyed at all because I know how some shops they just can't wait to close and go home! However, she had a smile, very welcoming attitude as we walked in. She suggested Titanic, and a super dark roasted espresso which I forgot the name but was definitely robust enough to be my taste.  The space is extremely small and intimate, and there's some seating in the back as well. I love their decorations, however next time I'm coming back again to order their latte! 
Before we left, the miss barista said we made her day, well, you made ours by suggesting great coffee choices!

Hope to see you again soon!

Cheers!
author: Joey K.

description: hollow is a sanctuary. Savor your latte here- some real care and attention has gone into it. The environment  is cozy and slow- the perfect hide out for a journal entry or two or three or five. Leave your laptop at home- don't mess with this vibe.
author: Richie B.

description:
Really charming shop.
Strong espresso. Decent lattes. On the pricier side. 
The feel of the shop is more attractive than the drinks itself. I'll return though.
author: Mary R.

description: I've passed this place so many times and their signature green building always caught my eye. It's really small inside, but I like that it's cozy! There's a few tables in the front and 3 tables in the back that can fit maybe like 6 people at most. I had seen photos of their Titanic II which is their sipping chocolate and house made vanilla bean marshmallow and I was really excited to try it. Then I looked at the menu and saw that that one cup of hot chocolate was $8.25....WHAT!??! Even authentic sipping chocolate in Santa cruz with beans that were imported was cheaper than that or the place near Palo Alto that house makes their marshmallows was also cheaper. Even someone ridiculous as me who would normally be willing to dish out a couple extra dollars to try things was not willing to try that. I instantly silently judged everyone I've seen who has tried the drink LOL. Welp, oh well. I had asked the cashier if they could make the spiced matcha just a normal matcha (so without the cinnamon and whatever else) and he didn't hear me so I let it go. I opted for the butterscotch latte because I'm a huge fan of butterscotch flavor anything. Upon receiving it, it was lukewarm at best even though I got it right when he called it out. Being a barista, I don't understand how you can make a drink the wrong temperature since you have to use the thermometer to steam milk and you're very aware of when you stop it at 140-160 degrees, but whatever. The drink was very, very bland and didn't seem to have the smallest hint of butterscotch. Tasted like a plain latte that wasn't very strong. Ehhh. I saw they serve empanada's that I would be willing to come back and try!
author: Maleah M.

description: A charming and quaint little coffee shop with cute/good lattes but beyond an initial 'omg this place is so cute,' nothing else was really memorable here for me. The place, although absolutely adorable, is a little small to either study or catch up with a group of friends. And the lattes, which were pretty good, weren't amazing, especially for $5.
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
I love the space. Very cozy and hipster-like. 

Hollow offers delicious pastries and some good coffee drinks. The matcha latte and the artisan mocha are great options. The Belgian waffle and chocolate filled croissant are also very tasty. Prices, however, are a little higher than expected and the small cup size is indeed quite small. Drinks also take a long time to make as compared to other coffee shops.
author: Tunaidi A.

description:
Cute, quaint, hipster vibe, this place has got these adjectives locked down. And in true hipster fashion, their coffee is also very expensive. A small is about 1.5 times the size of an express shot. The large is the size of the tall at Starbucks. If you think Starbucks is overpriced, this place has got them beat. Their prices also beat coffee bought in the financial district, where the rent would at least justify higher costs. But I guess in a city where $70k is considered low income, it makes sense to support the cause and gauge your customers. 

Oh I should also comment on how their drinks tasted. Tried the matcha tea latte and French press. Eh, nothing to write home about.
author: Ivy T.

description: The coffee is good, but it's SUPER EXPENSIVE compared to how much they give. Their large size is SO SMALL compared to how much you will get at other coffee shops -- especially when I get an iced latte (the ice is half of the already very small cup). Otherwise the cafe itself is very cute and very San Francisco hip style. I would go there once in a while when I want to enjoy the atmosphere, but it's definitely not a place that I would go often just to get coffee.
author: Erika S.

description: Delicious! First time that I have tried a Matcha Latte and honestly, I absolutely loved it!! Never experienced nothing like that! So good.. Great service, friendly, very kind, pleasant people. Also, great choices on chocolates bars. Everything in a reasonable price. My toddler had a hot chocolate. Delicious!
author: Carol M.

description: After reading a bunch of reviews, I had really high hopes for Hollow. We tried their dark chocolate mocha and chai latte and both were not good, both drinks barely had any flavor. The dark chocolate mocha was pretty pricey and it tasted like steamed milk and a little bit of dark chocolate. The chai latte was pretty much the same, it lacked the chai spice flavor and was more watery. Maybe it was the girl who made our drinks because we did overhear that she just started working there, I'd be willing to give Hollow another try but my first experience was not a good one.
author: Tammy P.

description: Truly one of the city's best kept secrets. This place is known for its butterscotch lattes and dark mochas (which are made with chocolate from a local, artisan chocolatier), but their coffee has such an integrity to it, I hate to complicate it. A simple cappuccino here is smooth as silk and rich with notes of Ritual's seasonal espresso; if I can find a table, I pair it with one of their brown butter chocolate chip cookies (which they bake right behind the counter), and I'm not sure there's a better way to pass an afternoon.
author: Izana N.

description: Great coffee, great people, great vibe....and such a nice place to have a chat.  Kid friendly. Just a sweet place.
author: David K.

description:
Certainly hip, maybe a little snobby, but definitely worth a stop if you're in the neighborhood. I was staying with a friend who lived a few blocks away from Hollow so it became my first stop every morning before I'd head out for the day. 

They have your basic brews and milk options (including almond and soy) and a few fancy coffee offerings as well. I tried both their butterscotch and vanilla lattes and they were both very tasty. The butterscotch is homemade and the vanilla latte was filled with little bits of real vanilla beans. They have a few baked offerings as well, standouts are the cinnamon roll biscuits and the Guinness cupcakes. There's also a pretty big selection of extra-fancy locally produced chocolates, that are kinda pricey but worth it if you're looking to buy gifts for your extra-fancy chocolate loving friends. 

So why only four stars and not five? The service was really spotty. Some days I'd be greeted with a smile and a bit of chat from the barista on duty, and other days I left the shop feeling like I was interrupting the B.O.D.'s personal solitude party. I get it. I hate dealing with most people basically always, and for sure gave the guy working the counter that day the benefit of the doubt, but had the same experience when I went in the next morning. It wasn't enough to keep me away (see the first paragraph, it was literally down the street from where I was) but definitely kept me from ordering anything more than a basic iced coffee from there on out, at the risk of spending more time inside the shop than necessary and thus prolonging the winsome barista's return to peace and quiet.
author: AuraLee P.

description:
Charming little shop in Sunset.  This place is tiny with limited seating in front and back of the shop.

Drinks are overpriced (for a tinyyy small cup) and sadly disappointing.  Both Vanilla bean latte and butterscotch latte lacked flavor and reminded me of a regular latte.  Given the small space and only 2 people working at a time, expect slow service.

Bottomline is great ambience but drinks were just ok.  Maybe the pastries are better.
author: Angel W.

description:
Stood in front of the guy waiting for him to be ready to take our order, while he just talks with his buddy about his new piano lessons. 

Vanilla bean latte and butterscotch latte taste the same. Tastes just like milk.

In all of San Francisco and the hipster coffee spots that I've been to, this one takes the cake as the most hipster, with the most tight butthole barista I've ever had the displeasure of sharing oxygen with. To Mr. scarf, thick-rimmed glasses, 20-min hair gel, I applaud your ability to draw a leaf on a cup of coffee and your private banjo and piano lessons.
author: Gary W.

description:
This is third time coming here . The first time I came with my friend, we ordered their butterscotch latte and vanilla bean marshmallow latte. I didn't really like the vanilla bean latte because it was to sweet for me ( if you are someone who loves sweeter drinks and marshmallows, you would definitely like this one.) on the other hand, their butterscotch latte was really good. My friend and I both really enjoyed that drink . It also wasn't to sweet. 
Vanilla Bean Marshmallow Latte ( 3/5) 
Butterscotch Latte (5/5)

The second time we went to hollow, we ordered their   Chai Green Tea Latte and it was amazing. You could taste the green tea and it was to sweet, it was just right . The latte art was also really beautiful! 

For our third visit, I tried their dark chocolate mocha and my friend had their chai spiced matcha latte again. The mocha was  pretty good and wasn't too sweet. We also tried their empanadas which were really delicious.

They also have a room in the back that you can go sit and enjoy your coffee with friends!! Overall I would rate this place (5/5) 

I would definitely come back here again!!!
author: Sophia L.

description: Someone else described this as a hidden gem, and I totally got that vibe, too. We were being tourists in the area and my husband was craving a latte, so we popped in to check it out. Upon first glance it is absolutely adorable, like something out of a fairy tale, but it is TINY in there -- there were maybe three tiny tables in the front area and you felt like you were right up in the lap next to you, it was close. But it seemed like there may have been seating down the hall (we saw some people leaving after we came in) so that may help. My husband had a butterscotch latte and I had a hot chocolate -- both absolutely delicious! -- and we shared a peanut butter cookie (okay, I ate the whole thing because DAMN IT WAS GOOD). Cute spot!
author: Justine J.

description: The sweetest baristas and the coziest little gem in the area! Got a hot chocolate with a marshmallow and it was heavenly! Definitely worth the trek out here don't miss it if you're in the area!
author: Nadine C.

description:
This place has been on my bookmark of places to go for quite some time. I love the quaintness of this little cafe. From the wooden interior design to the outside of the shop. I just love the simplicity and minimal look of the cafe. I got the vanilla bean latte. It was pretty good, but not memorable. This would be my ideal place to sit and read a book or even work a little. My main purpose coming here today was actually to work. However, upon entering, I didn't feel welcomed. There was almost his awkwardness to the guy that was there today. A few minutes later another worker comes in. She gave me this look as I was trying to take the perfect picture to share with the world to show how cute their coffee shop was. I really couldn't get out of there fast enough. I finished my vanilla bean latte and snapped one picture of the outside and left. I may come back at a different time hoping it's two different employees, but I've never felt more uncomfortable at a coffee shop in my life. I was so excited for this spot that I was rushing to get here just to make sure I get a seat. 

I'm a customer service nut and what was shown to me today was not up to par. Coming from the food and restaurant industry and years of customer service experience, if I was an undercover customer trying to scope the employees and business out, they would not pass in my book. I had such high hopes for this place. It's obviously a popular place to go especially for esthetics in pictures.
author: Sheena C.

description:
My other favorite coffee shop nearby was packed so I finally opted to come visit here. It's a SUPER small shop with like 6 seats but lo and behold! The day I decided to come and study with friends was the day that the back area opened up for business. There was an additional 3 custom-made tables on flimsy car jacks and seating for at least 8 more people and a whole bunch of space for retail goods and some refrigerators for kombucha. 

The baristas were super friendly and the green tea I ordered was presented with a nice little tea pot set. 

There's no wifi here and the reception with Verizon totally sucked so it was a bit difficult to do our collaborative computer work...so that would be my only desire to lure me in again to study. Still, I'll be back!
author: Sam L.

description:
You know what's great? This place.

Seriously. I mean, how crazy-cool are those knickknacks (I want those gold salt-and-pepper shakers!), the goat's milk soaps and hand creams? Very. I'd never guess they'd look so nice beside my coffee. And not just any coffee, mind you. Incredible-tasting butterscotch lattes (with house-made butterscotch) that's not cloyingly sweet: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hollow-san-francisco?select=58bIOs6RHeBHk3Kqr1kCjg#l55bvOQ030hLzM4-xv2P6Q and yummy chais.

Sure there aren't loads of indoor tables, and yeah, you can hear Lindsey's conversation with Jen about how lame Shane's party was last weekend, but this place is still cool. Just put on some headphones and blast Explosions in the Sky, you'll be OK.

I'll be back for those empanadas and gluten-free PB-chocolate-chip cookies everyone raves about. This time, I'll come with a pair of headphones, too.
author: Adena B.

description:
I don't understand how people can say that this place is pretentious and offers terrible drinks. It's such a cute coffee shop in the middle of the sunset. The cafe itself is small, but it's elaborately decorated and offers seating inside and outside. 

I also don't understand how people are complaining about the price of the drinks. Yes, the price is a little higher than the average, but it's good quality coffee beans and you're supporting a small, local business. 

The lattes here are rich in flavor and they offer many flavors such as butterscotch, vanilla bean (with actual vanilla beans), matcha, and much more. It's so pretty to look at too! The empanadas are heavenly, but they are tinier than I am used to. Haven't tried their desserts/pastries yet, but they look scrumptious.

This place is definitely another hidden gem in the sunset. Try it out!
author: Lisa H.

description:
Does Ritual Coffee mean you get 1 x 1 sq ft to sit? Is that the ritual?

I like the coffee here, but environment is lacking. Would function better as a stand.
author: Rafael S.

description:
You'd normally walk past this place without giving it a second thought, but this shoebox-sized shop manages to pack in an espresso machine, two servers, three tiiiiiny tables with room for two each, and oodles of soaps, trinkets, and novelty items.

The coffee is darn good (I could taste right away that it was Ritual beans) and the food offerings, particularly the empanadas, are quite good as nice, small snacks. Service is super courteous and friendly. If you're a taller or bigger person, just take care not to overturn the table or knock stuff off the shelves when you're getting up - it's that tiny a space.

A veritable hipster hangout that, like ya, sooooo totally brings new meaning to the term "hole in the wall."
author: Vincent L.

description:
What to do when you are too early for dinner? Grab a cup of tea at a charming little coffee shop.

Hollow with it's rustic chic design is definitely a charming little place. It's very hard to order a drink without a little something to nibble on from the deliciously looking pastries they have. 

If you had to pick something small do try the marshmallow! It's devine!!! 

The place is quite cozy, they have an additional room in the back with some seating and goodies! 

Lovely little place for a quite and intimate coffee or to sit alone with your thoughts, your books... 

I loved everything about Hollow!
author: Tamara S.

description: Such a cute coffee shop! Its really small so big groups would not fit here. My friends and I were up from San Jose and after enjoying dinner we walked over to Hollow. My friend had been before so she recommended we go. It was Sunday around 6 when we arrived and there were a few people inside sitting at the two tables they have. They have some unique items for sale aside from coffee. I decided to try the house made Vanilla bean latte with almond milk. I usually get a mocha but it sounded so good. There was one barista since the place is tiney. She was really nice and made each coffee one at a time instead of juggling multiple orders. The hot latte was served with a heart in the foam. So cute! I also bought a vanilla bean marshmallow. It was good. If you like chocolate try the titanic. It's a hearty drink with a marshmallow on top!
author: Evangelina B.

description:
Saw this place on Yelp. Decided to give it a try since we were in the area.

We heard a lot about the empanadas so we each got a mushroom one. I also got a chai latte.

$3.75 for a very small cup of chai latte, (which was more on the spicy side with a touch of sweetness) and $11 for two small empanadas (priced at $5.50 each). The mushroom empanadas were very strong, due to the cheese that was used. If I were to come back, I would have a different flavor.

Overall, a small hole in the wall with good aesthetics that's located in a small neighborhood. It's your usual hipster cafe.
author: Guilliana J.

description:
Espresso drinks only.

Really small location with a dark hipster feel. I got weird vibes from this place especially because the baristas didn't even smile once. The atmosphere is not very inviting. 

I ordered a small butterscotch latte with soy (+50 cents) and my bf ordered a decaf latte. The total came out to $7.25, which was was pricey considering the fact that their "small" cups are a size down from a small cup you'd find in any other coffee shop. My butterscotch latte was quite tasty with a nice sweet and salty balance, but it was just warm and not piping hot like it should be. The latte art doesn't make up for it. I probably would not go out of my way to come back.
author: Stephanie G.

description: The cutest little cafe in SF!!!  Everything about this place is charming!  Love their tea selection and coffee drinks.  Will definitely return.
author: Katelyn G.

description: A roomy hole-in-the-wall type of place. It's a good place to keep warm and drink some coffee if you wanna hide from the SF chill. The menu isn't too extensive. I ordered the matcha latte, which wasn't too sweet. It did have an interesting "kick" to it though.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This place had to have been a garage previously lol but it's pretty damn amazing. 

Basically a single person barista with great espresso. The iced coffee is limited each day so if that's your thing I believe it ran out around 3 on Saturday for reference on a pretty nice day. 

Got the vanilla latte which is homemade vanilla to flavor it and you could see all the specks of the vanilla bean and it was so good. My mom never drinks lattes but she drank about all of mine. It was a nice vanilla flavor that came through, very fresh and warm. 

Great spot I would recommend to check out and they have some nice little drinking items in the back. The guy in front of us bought a rabbit wine stopper and we bought a bear face bottle opener so they were unique enough to hook us. 

Check this spot out!
author: Eric R.

description:
So I am totally in love with this little coffee shop.  The aesthetic inside and outside of the shop is super charming, the things I have ordered are tasty treats for my mouth, and their little knick knacks...ugh!  I can't.  I just want everything here.  

I went with a friend today. We got: 

- Butterscotch Latte...YAASSSS!!!! House made butterscotch in a latte. You need to try this if you like coffee and butterscotch.  Do it!
- Beef Empanada...Lovely.  I'm digging this empanda.  It had a sweet hint to it from the raisins, but still a delicious savory treat with the beef and the olives.  
- Dark Chocolate Mocha...a bit too chocolatey for my dear friend, but she drank it a; so whatevs.
- Chicken sausage empanada...I definitely approve.  It was like a pot pie, but it was an empanada.  Can't go wrong with that.  
- Cinnamon bun biscuit.  I always get this and the butterscotch latte...so I likey a lot.   

Try this place if you're looking for a good coffee shop.  I am looking forward to trying their vanilla latte and their mushroom and gorgonzola empanada.  See you again soon, Hollow!
author: Jess G.

description:
Hollowed out. Yum!

I enjoyed their spinach ricotta empanada and a regular latte. I was beyond satisfied on a beautiful Saturday morning.

This is a bit of a walk from the busy inner sunset, but this tiny gem is tucked in the middle of the inner and outer sunset on 14th street.

While the place is a tight squeeze with a few  places to gather and order drinks, it is still very charming. Go here to catch a break.
Catch your breath. Enjoy a cup of joe. And proceed with your (busy) life. I enjoy the calming atmosphere and will definitely take walks for a cup.

Worth every stride.

One star off though for pricing. It's a bit ridiculous but you pay good mula for a nice time.
author: Bern M.

description: Cute little cafe. We got the iced butterscotch latte & the mocha. Both were very good! The butterscotch latte was very smooth & the mocha wasn't too sweet.
author: Diane H.

description: Really cute coffee place with nice decor! The spiced green tea latte was DELICIOUS and the titanic 2 was alright. HOWEVER, the customer service could've been better. Both the workers' energy levels could've been higher and a little more enthusiastic.
author: Meagan C.

description:
Cute little cafe.AWESOME coffee and specialty drinks! Not a place for studying, too small. it's mainly for relaxing cafe type places. 
They open kind of  late and close kind of early!
author: Ramin A.

description:
Loved everything about this cafe from the drinks to the decor to the service! This place gives off a very rustic/shabby chic vibe; it's small but cozy, and beautiful in it's simplicity. I was surprised that this place was located in such a residential-ish area (further away from the popular eateries along Irving St.) that could easily be missed! This place has very limited seating so not ideal for groups; it's a great spot to catch up with a friend or get a grab-n-go.  There are a few more tables further inside with lots of natural bath and body products and chocolate! 

I ordered a small spiced matcha green tea latte - boyyy was this a satisfying drink! It was rich in flavor and not overly sweet. I couldn't pinpoint what the spice was..probably cinnamon? It was very difficult not to inhale the whole thing in less than a minute! I would go back and order this again and again.
I also tried my friend's vanilla bean latte - it was a very pleasant drink, with a wonderful aroma from the fresh vanilla beans. I thought it was slightly less sweet compared to mine.Towards the end of drinking, all the grains from the vanilla bean collected at the bottom and my friend kinda choked on it lol. 

The drinks were reasonably priced for the quality. They also have a variety of teas, pastries, cookies, savory items such as empanadas. I like they share a short list of ingredients used in some of the baked goods - none of them weird processed stuff!
Next time I'll come back and try their black coffee as I'm curious about the quality of their coffee beans. :)

On another note, unfortunately, they do not have wifi. :[
author: Anna L.

description: Cozy hole-in-the-wall cafe near Golden Gate Park. Their butterscotch late is delicious! They have friendly baristas and light seating along the walls.
author: Dara M.

description:
Was deciding between the vanilla or butterscotch latte (both says handmade) when they told me they ran out of vanilla.. butterscotch it is.  It was not too sweet with a deep flavor.

small place with about 2 small tables inside and 2 outside.  lots of cool soaps and gadgets to look at inside.

service was friendly
author: Linda T.

description: Good mocha but I still feel like eight dollars for an artisanal dark chocolate soy mocha was pretty expensive at such a small size. Maybe I'm just not enough of a coffee snob, but I really did love the wood feel and 1920s music of the tiny café. I would recommend it!
author: Martie A.

description:
This place is tiny but super cuteee, from the decor outside to the  small trinkets inside, wooden bench/tables inside. Not much seating, two tiny tables and one wooden bench. They sell a cool bottle opener in the shape of a bear's mouth and some metal straws which I found amusing. The menu isn't very extensive and very minimal, which makes choices easier to make. 

I had the butterscotch latte and I was super excited expecting it to taste like a harry potter butter beer for some reason. It was just okay though, a lot saltier than I expected. 

But since the decor and the service here is amazing, I'll definitely be back for more if I'm ever around. + they use coffee beans from ritual.
author: Michelle H.

description:
The exterior of this little coffee shop is adorable. I walked into this place without reading any reviews and it felt nice to take in a new cafe with no presumptions or expectations. 

I ordered the matcha latte, not the special one (they have two) but somehow the barista still made me the special one. Maybe it's just the one everyone orders.. But it was gingery, and I don't really like ginger. It was drinkable but it took me a really long time to put it down, and it was delicious if not for the ginger. If you love ginger, this matcha latte is for you! 

The seating is cramped and minimal but that keeps noise level low since only 5 or 6 people can sit at once. 

They sell chocolates and other goodies in the front too! I'd definitely come back and order something new, or just specify that I really don't want the special one.
author: Kelly H.

description: I live very close to Hollow but I've only been inside once last year.  My gf and I ordered a couple drinks and empanadas.  The drinks were forgettable but not bad.  However, the server got my gf's empanada order wrong but instead of acknowledging that and just fixing the order.. he was a complete asshole.  That was that last time I went to Hollow.  Instead, we just go down to Snowbird where I've never had anyone be hella rude and the drinks are so much better.
author: Laura R.

description:
A small, unnoticeable cafe. It's very vintage inside and very cozy. 

I ordered a latte and it also came with a cute little picture on top :). The latte came and was definitely picture worthy. It tasted like a thick, foamy drink. It was my first time trying it and don't know if I like it but still great. 

The person who helped me was very nice and definitely earned 5 stars for her work.
author: Vernice T.

description:
4 stars because 

+ Cutest setting ever. Everything is just adorable and all I wanted to do was stare at all the decor
+ didn't try the treats but they all looked delicious. Also all local
+ barista is so knowledgable and honest! I love it when I can ask questions about the menu and get tips, recommendations, personal favorites and honesty if he/she's never tried it before - he did just that! 
+ great quiet location in inner sunset 

I only got a cloud mist tea since I'm a tea drinker but it was still good! 

I would say, this isn't a place to hang out for too long, seating is limited (2 small tables and a bench or two). Great place for a quick catchup in a quiet neighborhood.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Steve, the dark barista with the hair and the smile, is so nice it's scary. The FedEx guy who stops by sometimes seems pretty cool too...

But do they get along?

It's probable. Also, what day is it? Thursday? Monday? 

There are magnifying glasses here for 65 dollars. But Steve is free. And when you watch him do it - you're in deep. I am here right now, in fact. Come on by. The chamomile tea makes my stomach soft and ready. 

It'd be interesting if they sold a few handguns - I mean, it'd just be interesting.
author: Aaron C.

description: The cutest neighborhood coffee shop! We shared a cinnamon swirl biscuit which was warm and delicious. I had a vanilla bean latte with a giant handmade marshmallow square plopped inside. It was aaaaahmazing! An Americano with a splash of almond milk was also enjoyed. Grab a seat and soak in the atmosphere or stop by their little gift shop next door and pick up a "just because" hide sir someone special.
author: Karen A.

description: This place is so awesome and the stuff are super friendly. I fell in love with this place as soon as as I walked in .this place deserves more than 5 stars .
author: Mohammed A.

description: Can't deny hollow's coffee is great. But food and pastries are getting smaller and more expensive. Empanada is tiny bit and costs $5.5
author: Carrie Z.

description: Small but digging the vintange ambiance. The art and furniture adds to the vintange theme well. Everytime I've been here coffee is freshly brewed.  Not sure if their still lacking in wifi but great place to socialize. Pastreis are good I remembered but haven't tried that many tbh.
author: Jude N.

description:
Delicious espresso!! Sweet and perfect. The Spanish chicken empanada was delicious with a little kick of spiciness. 
Cozy place but gets a little challenging with a very narrow entrance.
author: Maly F.

description:
Got a couple decent french press coffees, but don't linger if you have kids. We asked for our drinks to stay since it was raining, but they put them in to-go cups anyway in between prison stares for my toddler that was spinning their ridiculous old-timey table tops.

Just not for families, which is fine. I make pretty good coffee at home anyway.
author: Alex L.

description:
This place is such a cool lil cafe, and when I say "lil," I mean it. It's more of "get your coffee and bounce" kind of spot. There are two tables and a bench, so realistically, you can cram 10 people inside for seating. This is the only criticism I have for Hollow, hence the 4 stars instead of 5.

The coffee is great, as is the decor. If you're ever in the area, it's def an awesome spot in the sunset district.
author: Aaron C.

description:
The smalls are small but perfect. Not too small like acre ;)

The beef empanada! So good! They heat them up so hot and steamy! The shell is puffy and nice. The filling is ground beef with raisins and olives. Also, it looks small but it's substantial and kept me full for four hours.

There is french press coffee available if you don't want an espresso drink.
author: Jacquee P.

description: Hollow is a hole-in-the-wall café near the edge of Inner Sunset, just one block north of the N and one block south of the park. The set up of the café has you feel like you're entering a hallway; at probably 200sf, with room for no more than ten people, it really is just a nook. After weeks of walking by, I stopped in one Friday afternoon on my way to the grocery store. The barista asked me how my day had been going, handed me my slice of banana bread ($3.50), and carefully poured a 12oz latte ($4.50). The pastry selection was small, just four or five items ranging from $2 to $5, but bags of Ritual coffee and gourmet chocolate lined the shelves. It's clear the café is well kept; it's humble but immaculate. Walking out, I noticed a menu by the window, easy to miss if you are accustomed to heading directly for the counter. I'll take a closer look at it next time. I'm sure I will be back.
author: Brian C.

description:
Been checking out cafés whenever and wherever I can. Made a trip to San Francisco and saw the reviews his place and decided to give it a shot.
Was worth it. It's not overly priced and got the butterscotch latte as suggested by someone else. It wasn't overly sweet so yum! 
Also for a chocolate croissant that was super good and flakey. 
There were other things in there I wanted to buy like the fillet mignon jerky and different types of chocolate but didn't want to spend too much money and will save it for another visit. :)
author: Sophia S.

description:
Everything I have tried here is excellent - coffee, lattes and pastries.  
First of all, it is a cute little nook of a coffee shop, love the neighborly vibe. (they are adding more sitting room in the back)  The people are really nice although sometimes stressed because all us coffee drinkers seem to travel in packs and descend upon them at the same time.  But please no worries, the coffee is made in the best way possible so no shortcuts.  I am happy to wait for the deliciousness I receive in return.
author: Kirsten F.

description:
Either the barista thinks he's better than me or he's just really shy. I love this place regardless! 

Super small space with really limited seating options. I agree that ordering is a bit confusing and awkward, but I'm used to being confused and awkward so I honestly don't mind!

The decor of this place is gorgeous in a really effortless kind of way. I love the side shop that they have going on! Really whimsical with the metal straws, perfume, and rocket-shaped tea steepers. I dig it! 

Order your drink to go because their to go cups are really nice and minimalistic. I stared at mine for a while and then gave it a photo shoot while I was at the San Francisco Botanical Garden afterwards! Not quite sure how to take the cup's advice though since I nearly always take my coffee from strangers....
author: Shasta L.

description:
Time to update my review of little lovely hollow. 

I had previously mentioned that customer service left much to be desired. That is no longer the case. The ladies I've interacted with now are so kind and approachable. So not only are you getting great ambiance, great espresso, and more seating, you are also getting a great experience! Don't forget the amazing food! Cheers!
author: Tessa R.

description:
Best coffee ever.  It is SLOW (so if you are in a rush, skip it), but it's worth the wait.  It must take a while to make perfection.  I also love the unique gift items for sale and styling of the interiors.  Recommendations: Soy Lattes, Butterscotch Lattes, and the Cinnamon Biscones, and Handle caramel.  I also love the TokyoMilk perfumes and lotion line.  

The owners have opened up a beautiful little gift shop next door, Dandy, that is definitely worth a gander.  Unlike the cozy little hobbit hole of Hollow, Dandy is bright and airy with a Swedish feel.  The owners and employees of both are lovely.
author: Allegra H.

description: Service was friendly, and actually very quick considering the reviews. Coffee was smooth and flavorful. Got a vanilla bean latte, which was not at all too sweet!
author: Ashley T.

description: Decided to come to this coffee shop because we saw many of our friends post pictures on instagram. We decided to pay a visit. It literally looks like a wooden hole in the wall. The vibe is definitely hipster so I'm glad yelp has a category to choose from that includes this. You walk in and there are locally made items to buy which are very cool but outside my personal taste. I declined to purchase any trinkets and decided to go for the coffee. They have a cup of coffee for around $7. The only thing I could tell that was different was they put a house-made vanilla bean marshmallow on top of a latte. Tasty but not worth the money no matter how amazing the marshmallow was, it's not made of gold. I would like to come back and get a regular latte to satisfy my coffee fix.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
Not a coffee drinker so can't say anything about that category (but the friends I've brought here have liked it). 

But I will say their hot cocoa with marshmallow ($4) is quite tasty-- a decaffeinated play on the titanic II. The space is a cute hole-in-wall joint with 4 little tables and a couple beaches, but it's cozy and intimate if you can snag a spot! No wifi, but the space doesn't really lend itself to getting heavy work done any way. Spend a nice day catching up with a friend away from your laptop/phone! 

They also have a nice selection of teas that come in small pots, and they'll normally refill your hot water if you want. I've had their empanadas as well--good but nothing too extraordinary. Some coffee drinks are a bit pricy ($5.50 mocha and $8.50 titanic II), but the place is a worth a visit. Not sure if it'd be my regular spot though.
author: Erin N.

description:
I wish i could dock a star simply because I didn't find this place sooner, but that's my bad.

Hollow is the epitome of a spot I would love. Its quaint, warm, simple and offers a great product. When coming in, you'll notice a simple menu with a few food items. Aside from the obvious, youll also see a lot of other items for sale ranging from chocolates, perfumes and even spoons... all from local small business'. Anyone who knows me knows that I go out of my way to patronize small business' so I appreciate the approach.

Ordered a latte and sat outside to enjoy the day. The coffee is from Ritual so you can expect your drink to be nothing less than awesome.

This is my new go-to while im working out here (sorry uncle bennys and sbux)... but this little green box has stolen my heart, even if I have to walk 12 blocks to get my fix.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Cute little coffee shop. Very tight though. And they aren't terribly accommodating when it comes to making drinks. Was told they couldn't make a triple cappuccino. Huh?

Overall it is nice to have in the neighborhood, but the execution isn't as good as many of the other premium coffee shops in SF.
author: JM H.

description: This cafe is pretty hip and quaint, unconventionally designed and has a wood theme. Definitely on the smaller side but good for a group of 2 or 3. I ordered the dark chocolate mocha and it was pretty bomb, though more on the chocolate side and a little pricey ($5.50 ish for a small cup).
author: Leanna W.

description: Very small but definitely cute and cozy. It's right down the street from San Tung kitchen. I ordered their butterscotch latte and it was delicious. Very smooth and the butterscotch wasn't too sweet or overpowering. I noticed they have various pastries that all looked divine. A little on the pricier side but definitely something to try.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Went here and was excited to try the Titanic II but they raised it up to $8.50!! I understand that the marshmellow is homemade and they use expensive cacoa but pretty ridiculous to charge a drink as much as I would pay for a sandwich. 

Ended up getting a spiced matcha which was good and an empanada ($5.50), small, overpriced, handmade, good but not enough filling. 
The bf got a mocha which was decently good. 

Baristas were great. 

Overall, this place has 3 small tables and is very small and cute. 
No wifi, no problem, but for some..
author: Dede C.

description:
Oh how I love a great, high-quality, cup of coffee. Yes, Hollow's coffee is indeed good. And yes, they have that rustic, driftwood, industrial low-lighting look that has become oh-so popular with all the coffee shops these days. 

Be sure to stop by if you want to feel as though you are not good enough to even wait in the slowest 2 person line you've ever seen. Be sure to come here for your morning coffee if you thrive on starting your day with a pretentious barista (yes tall, thin, dark haired guy - I mean you) who's time is too precious to acknowledge your presence in the quaint cafe even when you are the only other person besides his buddy that he is chatting with. The expressionless face, with a hint of subtle annoyance, when you ask for coffee to-go is enough to make you feel like you're asking an im-too-good-for-this teenager to help you set the table. Deeeelightful.

Suggestion Hollow? You are a neighborhood cafe, begin focussing on your customers with a genuine, warm, authentic disposition. Create a community vibe between customer and barista, rather than the feeling that you hope I choke on the coffee you just poured me. Would love to love the place, but needs an attitude adjustment.
author: Lou D.

description:
3.5 to 4 stars for me.

I came in with friend while it was pouring rain about about a week ago. When I entered, there was just one other person who dined it. 

On Yelp, what seems popular is the Homemade Vanilla Latte and Homemade Vanilla Bean Marshmallow so I got an order of both, total came to $5.75. They have cute dining ware and pretty designs with your lattes, they even have tongs to help yourself to the marshmallow.

My friend had to use the restroom and the entrance to it was a sheer white ish type of door which I would say is a pretty entrance haha. I'd come back but would skip the marshmallow just cause I've already tried it but would recommend you to try it at least once.
author: Yeanne L.

description:
What a cute little place! 

The staff were very friendly and my latte was creamy and tasty. I think it could have been served a bit warmer, as even the first sip tasted a little lukewarm. And my only other complaint is the prices. Their sizes seem smaller than other coffee shops around but the prices are the same or higher. 

The pastries looks amazing and though I didn't get one, I definitely won't pass them up on my next visit.
author: Marilyn M.

description: First time at this coffee shop. Found it on Pinterest & I thought it was the cutest thing. When in w my friend & her baby & my two year old toddler. Not the best idea to bring two little ones, it's super tiny in there. So we ordered our lattes. The latte art was not the best I've seen. We decided to go outside w our mugs because there was a little bench to sit, well the person that was working at the time, he goes outside in a hurry he thought we were gonna leave & take the mugs. I found that quite rude.  My vanilla bean Latte was okay
author: BeAtriz J.

description: The spicy matcha green tea latte is AMAZING! Very tiny and cute cafe with a charming vibe but unfortunately there is no WiFi.
author: Neel P.

description: Far out west of SF in sunset... however very small but cute spot. Was a bit disappointed in the matcha latter but the vanilla bean marshmallow was great. Croissants are tiny but super buttery and delicious. Empanadas and cookies were also good too.
author: Christine T.

description:
The best cappuccino in the sunset and one of the best in the city. Beautiful and warm design!
you can also purchase great chocolate and other special items. Iv'e been here at least 6 times already. Today i tried the matcha latte, out of this world. very pleasing service. this time it was the owner  that made my drink. great guy to chat with. I don't write a lot of reviews but this place deserves to have a line at the door all day long. Oh, almost forgot, the chocolate chip cookie was the best iv'e had in years. I am a fan!
author: Eli E.

description: I recommend the matcha green tea latte. The spinach and mushroom empanadas were tasty, but pricey considering the size of the empanadas.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
A little nice coffee shop on Irving St. I noticed this place when I dropped off and picked up my godson at Jefferson School. So I checked this place out and I enjoyed this cute shop. 

I enjoy my latte here, a small latte here is a bit smaller than other places but strong. 

They accept cash/cards but no wifi.

Homemade snacks here are good as well.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: I never knew one of my favorite drinks - Matcha Green Latte - could be combined with one of my least favorite drinks - Chai tea - to create something so delicious that I would still be thinking about it 1 week later. Foamy froth and not too sweet. This drink is the perfect winter drink which makes it ideal for the constantly foggy, Sunset region of SF. The empanadas are good snacks to have as well! Really small place, but they have a back for some extra seatings if you're lucky! I didn't have a problem with any of the people working, but the guy barista wasn't working then.
author: Mandy C.

description: I've only come here once, and I will definitely come again for their chai matcha green tea latte. It is one of the best lattes I've ever had, and I have had quite a few.  The latte had a very deep matcha flavor with the small essence of chai flavor. It tasted really great, but the only thing I don't like are the paper straws. They're cute, but not really durable if you're not planning to finish your drink write away.
author: Ambur -.

description:
Went there a couple mins before closing and the person who was working was very nice and helpful. Then a swarm of people suddenly comes in after us and she was still nice. :) 

Also, the small coffee is small but it's worth it. Just order medium if you're used to Starbucks sizes.
author: Jackie T.

description: They have the best vanilla bean latte!  House made and not that artificial syrup.  They have great empanadas for a quick snack and yummy chocolate chip cookies.  They make their own baked goods.
author: Toun W.

description: Decent coffee, i prefer Home.  The inside is very cramped and not meant to study or lounge.  Tried both the cap and vanilla bean latte.  The Cap is okay, a little too milky (maybe the espresso they use is light) and the espresso didn't really come through.  I was also dissapointed that they messed up the latte heart.  The vanilla bean latte is pretty good, a nice hint of vanilla, but again the drink was too milky.  Maybe it was my fault since i got a small with single shot, but they should adjust the ratio accordingly.   I can't say i am a fan of Hollow coffee, its a decent average shop around this area, but if i had to drive out i would not come here and go to Home instead.
author: Terence N.

description:
A cute little coffee, pastry, and gift shop that reminded me of kawaii places in Japan. 

The space looks like half of a converted garage. It's tiny, but packs a a lot of great things. 

If you're claustrophobic then you may want to skip this, cause having more than six people in there can be a bit tight.
author: Theresa D.

description: Incredibly tasty butterscotch latte!  They are coffee artisans here, from the excellent quality of coffee beans, to the intricate designs to personalize each cup of coffee goodness! Awesome find! :)
author: Chase B.

description: Butterscotch late and Ghirardelli mocha -- both honestly tasted nearly the same, but they were both nice strong coffee. The girl making the coffee was very friendly, and the coffee was normally priced. Nice stop for a cup of coffee, and there is a decent amount of seating. I will come back to try the empanadas.
author: Nikita K.

description: I ended up at this place after getting locked out of my apartment, and I have to say it's a pretty hipster little cafe with just okay coffee. I liked the decor (typical accessories like stag antlers, vintage looking spoons, etc.), but felt like I overpaid on my tiny cappuccino! There's not a lot of seating so it's more of a get your coffee and go, but it's a nice spot if you need somewhere to hang out and chat with a friend.
author: Grace C.

description: My favorite neighborhood cafe and one of my faves in SF. I feel like I am in a little cozy place in the middle of Scotland or Ireland :) the coffee is great and the croissants are amazing. They sell lots of cute homemade gimmicks and sweets like local chocolate or honey. Love this place!
author: Anastasia N.

description: Heaven on earth. Lucky me, I love around the corner from it!  I highly recommend the Matcha lattes and the cinnamon biscuits. Mmmmmm!  Oh, and did I mention it's really freaking cute?!
author: Annie N.

description:
FOR THE LOVE OF GOD PLEASE GET REAL STRAWS

I know real straws aren't twee, but nobody wants a self destruct timer for their drink, counting down the seconds before their mouth is full of paper mâché.

I would probably get coffee here every day if you opened in the morning before people go to work, like normal coffee shops do.
author: Beth D.

description: Great, tiny, local coffee shop.  Same 3-4 people always there making the coffee and they are all good. Baked goods are also good as are empanadas.
author: Neil B.

description:
A pretentious cafe serving really,really bad coffee. We had two espressos and couldn't finish them - acid and cold. 
The food is equally forgettable, cakes are boring and with bad tasting frostings. 
Overall the worst coffee bar I have ever tried in SF. Creepy vibes on Saturday afternoons too.
author: Sarah O.

description:
Great coffee. Love the atmosphere.

Hollow, located on Irving 10, is a homely, hipster cafe, serving SF's renown butterscotch lattes. It's laidback and slow-moving. The pace may leave many impatient, but at least, they're friendly, enough to convince you that these types are probably Sunset's chill surfer types.
author: Jay C.

description:
One word: butterscotch
butterscotch
butterscotch
butterscotch
butterscotch

I love anything with butterscotch. When I heard this place had butterscotch lattes, I was immediately intrigued. 

Looked it up on yelp. Immediately thought, "holy moly this place would look cute on my instagram".

The butterscotch latte was delicious although it was sweeter than I anticipated. Very milky and the butterscotch was not too overpowering. Although sweet, it wasn't heavy and syrupy like normal dessert-like lattes. Normally, I hate milk foam but this one was delicious and the latte art was cute.

A good place to sit and chat, but this cafe is tiny. There are two tables and a bench along a wall, so expect it to get crowded. Parking is easy peasy lemon squeezy. NOT a place to camp out and study.

Will be back for dark chocolate mochas, empanadas and/or cupcakes. Whichever one will make me feel less guilty.
author: Shirley N.

description:
While driving back from a morning at Fort Funston running around and hiking with the pup, I was feeling a bit worn down and in need of a pick me up.  A quick look on the great Yelp App on my Samsung android phone shewed that I was neat Hollow and it had a solid 4+ star rating.

Somehow I lucked out with a parking spot right across the street and Sadie and I went in.

First thing that I notices was the great selection of little items for sale. With Christmas coming up I made a mental note to myself to come back here soon for a few little things.

Second thing I notices was the menu of snacks to munch on.  I was a little hungry and that pulled me right in.  The empanadas in particular looked great.

So ordered my latte and sprung for a waffle too.  Both were excellent.

The staff was great and the clientelle was also friendly - Sadie got her share of petting.

Definately will be back.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Overpriced coffee that isn't that good. I am sure the SF hipster l o v e s such a boutique coffee joint but it doesn't excuse blatantly overcharging for average drinks. On a side note... Who owns a coffee shop and opens it at 9 am? Tactical error... That's like opening a bar that is only open from 6am- noon. 

I suggest you get overpriced coffee at Starbucks down the street.
author: None O.

description:
After a fun day at the zoo, we wanted to wind down and have some tea/coffee in the Sunset area. After yelping for a bit, we found this little gem! The place is super cute and looks very pinteresty inside. They actually sell little trinkets inside. I ordered the green tea matcha spiced latte, which was really good! It was creamy, spicy, and really different. I also had a sip of the vanilla bean latte which was realllly yummy since it had fresh vanilla bean in there.

Would I come back? If I'm ever back in that area, yes!
author: Shrina S.

description: I spent the perfect misty San Francisco morning at this cafe, sipping a matcha latte and munching on a tasty mushroom gorgonzola empanada while doing some reading. It's not cheap, but it's dangerously close to my friend's apartment, which means there will be more visits in the future! I'll be back for the butterscotch latte.
author: Angeline P.

description: Probably the most cutest coffee shop I've ever walked into. However, I didn't really enjoy my butterscotch latte. Maybe my taste buds are weird but I couldn't taste any butterscotch. Also my cup was really small. I think I finished my drink in two gulps.
author: Amy X.

description:
Drinks: Good

Service: Freaking Awkward!

We walk in. No greeting. We look for menu and it's clear we want to order. Cashier makes eye contact and says nothing. 3 minutes of standing and guy says "we have a menu on the wall."

We get our drinks. We ordered a macaron and didn't get it. We ask for it and they say it's self serve. Maybe you could have explained that before...
author: Tina M.

description: Took and Uber to Hollow one day to figure out that my driver dropped me off a block away from the actual location... Awesome. But I did not have a problem finding this cute cafe on Irving! Came in to order a butterscotch latte and I was not disappointed by it! The barista was really nice. I liked the ambiance of the cafe - cozy and friendly! There was nobody else in the cafe at the time, so I had a chance to look around at all the little things they had displayed. The latte was kind of expensive, but what do you expect in SF? Had my drink in my hand within a couple of minutes and was on my way over to Cal Academy. Will definitely come back here when I am in the city!
author: Taylor H.

description: This place is so cute! Before you even enter the small little coffee shop, the storefront is adorable. The inside is small but well appointed - rustic, cozy, has a natural element feel to it. I stayed in the area last weekend and decided to check out Hollow since I saw that they had a delicious looking Green Tea Matcha Latte. I was glad I stopped by as the beverage was delicious indeed!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Cute and utterly hipster in a woodland creature kind of way. 

Chalkboard menu - check. 
Menu on a vintage window pane - check
Faux apothecary cabinets - check
Shabby chic seating - check
Reclaimed wood shelves - check
Thoughtfully curated trinkets (ie pepper shakers with bear heads) - check

I had a very good latte.
My main problem here is the servers were very unfriendly. It was a Sunday, there was a line, I was chill, doing my Sunday morning thing. But it was clerical, there was no smile. I also ordered a drip coffee and she was like "you mean a french press?". Sure, I just want a normal drip. I'm sorry I didn't memorize your menu. They don't take your name, they just bark out the drinks and leave them on sugar shelf. It's totally impersonal.

Basically if you're going to bother dressing up your spot to be like someone's living room, then you should create that atmosphere. It made me think that it was just some weird show of a place that had no substance. Like a taxidermy deer. Because it wouldn't have surprised me if they had one there.
author: Subie C.

description:
Stopped to get an Americano and a chai at hollow around 5:30 (they close at 6). There was ONE couple in front of me. The guy took their order and ignored me while I stood inches away from him. He took forger to make their drinks and I thought his bad attitude was comical at this point. 

He finally asked to take my order, no pleasantries, and turned away another couple (time is now 5:55). 

There's more to it, but suffice it to say this place has the MOST AWKWARD/BAD service for such an intimate "artisanal" coffee spot. 

Did I mention that the barista seemed high out of his mind on coke and was playing crazy ambient murder music?
author: Sam H.

description:
I'm conflicted with Hollow.  While they produce a great product and have a cool space to be in, their operations and customer service is severely lacking.
