If you are on a schedule and don't have 15-20 minutes to wait for a coffee, go to Starbucks on 19th, or just wait for wherever your commute takes you before procuring your crafted beverage.  If two or more people are ahead of you, forget about it.  

There is usually only one barista methodically pouring drinks, and it is a one cup-at-a-time operation- No multi-tasking here.  Baristas typically focus on whoever they are currently serving, ignoring the length of the line, or how long you've been waiting to order.  I once stood waiting for 10-15 minutes with crutches and a broken leg while the barista chatted it up with a patron about the SF music scene.  He seemed oblivious and indignant when I attempted to refocus his attention to bigger picture of retail craft coffee: customers=business=$$.
author: Todd N.

description: Waiting for 20 minutes for a cup of latte to go to be made is just ridiculous. Writing the review, still waiting... who knows how much longer it will take.
author: Tetiana D.

description:
Hollow is a great place. 
But it's a small place. I'm not a tall girl but I can reach up and touch the ceiling. NOT A BAD THING. It's a very cute coffee shop. They have a section in the back with more indoor seating and lots of random items that they're selling. 

I had the butterscotch latte when I went. It was a little bland but wasn't bad for what I paid for it. All their flavors are made in house and they use Ritual coffee (which I swear by) so it's pretty good. Definitely planning on coming back.
author: Tammy L.

description: Super cute and super small. I had the Titanic 2. It's a mocha with a giant marshmallow in it. Sugar overload? Yes! But it was tasty & made a great Instagram photo. Lol.
author: C A.

description:
I am really glad to see that I'm not the only one who was treated in a condescending and rude way by the woman behind the counter. I went in with a big smile on my face, looking forward to checking out Hollow for the first time, and I left with my little cup of Americano and a gray cloud over my head.

Let me preface this by saying that I am a super low maintenance customer, very easy to please. I had a question about one coffee description on the chalkboard. It was long and sounded wonderful, but I wasn't sure if it was just one kind of coffee or if it was a couple of different kinds. (Butterscotch, bourbon, other yum words...) I asked if it was all one coffee or a couple. She looked at me as if I were an idiot, and she said it's one. I felt a little dumb, but said it sounds delicious and I'd love a cup. She coldly told me it takes a long time to make that. (Yeah, I know, it's drip, been there, done that.) I said I was fine with that. She gave me an icy stare, so I said if she was busy -- she had two other people she was making coffee for, and I figured some people get stressed out easily -- I'll just have an Americano.

 "It's your choice. What do you want?" she said. If she said it in a nice way, I'd be like, "The butterscotchy special, please, I'm in no rush!" But she said it in an icy, condescending way that made me feel like I was a stupid dork, which is not at all a normal mode for me. "I'll have the Americano. I need to get out of here." I said it pleasantly, as if I had to go pick up my kids, so probably no one but me read into it. 

While waiting, I heard her being rude to the next customer, who asked for almond milk in something. So even then, I knew it wasn't just me. But reassuring to see the other one-star reviews. 

I give it 2 stars bc it's a very cute little place. Whoever owns the place put a lot of love and thought into the design. He or she might want to think again, though, about who they hire. I will definitely not be going back. (Please tell me the woman who served on April 18 was not the owner!)

Oh, haha, the coffee cup it says "Hollow: Never take coffee from strangers." Just thought that was mildly ironic in some way. ;)
author: Maria G.

description: The unpleasant cashiers ruined this cafe for me. It's very cute, but not worth more than one visit.
author: Michelle L.

description: They serve Ritual Coffee. That's probably enough to be awesome, but they also have friendly baristas who take their time to craft your cappuccinos. You can take that time to peruse the little pasties, all the knick-knacks and artsy creations lining the narrow cafe walls. Unfortunately it only has a few small tables, which usually makes it so you gotta take that lovely drink to go, but also makes it super intimate. Definitely a hidden gem a little ways from the bustling 9th/Irving.
author: Vivian H.

description: Fantastic breakfast empanadas! We had the veggies ones- love! A little pricey (especially considering their size), which was a bummer. Great cookies, coffee, and overall vibe.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Hmmm...I want to love this place because they serve "fancy" coffee in my own neighborhood but unfortunately it's been pretty hit or miss. What I would go back for is their mocha with high-end chocolate, it was an absolute treat down to the last bit. Their cappuccino, however, was downright bitter and I was done after the first sip. 

They also sell chocolate bars from Dandelion. Yes, they're outrageously expensive at $9, but they are also wonderfully memorable and make for great gifts. 

I'd go back for the mocha and to buy chocolate for a special occasion but would probably skip it otherwise.
author: Mattheus K.

description:
HOLLOW is NOT hollow when it comes to taste and the cool vibe.  

Guiness Beer Cupcakes! Yes. "Everyone knows that anything tastes better with alcohol!", says ADDA DADA. 

Wonderful PEANUT BUTTER CHOCOLATE CHIP COOKIES...there's a kick of chocolate in every bite. Heaven in a cookie. 

HOLLOW is paradise in the real San Francisco. Yes, there is a long wait, but its so worth the wait for the wonderful goodies and the slow laid-back vibe.
author: Addadada A.

description:
There are some spots in SF I wish I could crawl inside & live in.
Hollow is one of them.

- great knick-knack-y gifts & random gifts for friends/loved ones
- amazing espresso (looooove their mochas)
- their baked goods selection is yummy & their empanadas are scrumptious
- staff is friendly & the cafe is small, cosy & always smells oh-so nice!

Adopt me, Hollow.  Adopt me?
author: Anjali V.

description: Great spot! Cutest little place to grab a coffee and a quick bite! I go here every time I am in the area and I have never had anything I dont like from this place. Also, if they have a little sample tray sitting out, definitely grab whatever it is they are offering and enjoy. Service has always been off the charts here. Im always impressed with how well they handle several people lining up at the counter without switching over into the frantic vibe that you get at some coffee places. Way to go! I will always stop in when I am on this side of town!
author: Monica C.

description: Cute place but drinks were a bit over priced and were really milky.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
This place is small but very pretty inside. I love the entire design from the decor to the cups themselves, and the coffee is well crafted and tastes great. The thing is they don't seem to care one bit about service or practicality. It doesn't matter if you're in a rush, they will take their sweet time and not give one glimmer of care about you as a customer or human being. I've been there 5 times. 

One time I told them I wanted cream and sugar on the side to go because I didn't know what the people I was getting coffee for wanted. They were very annoyed and they didn't have any small containers for that so they poured cream into a regular sized coffee cup and scooped sugar into another. There weren't even lids on them. They didn't say a word to me the whole time, just slammed it on the counter. They wouldn't even look at me. Also I had to carry multiple cups in my arms because they don't ahve those holders for multiple cups. Every time I ask a question they act as if I'm the stupidest asshole in the room who is just inconveniencing them even though the place is always empty when I'm there. Despite all this I like the whole concept, look and coffee that I still find it kind of charming... I dunno. I'm never going back again though unless I have to.
author: Dexter H.

description:
Really good coffee, charming interior, but employees have the personality of drywall. I hate my job as much as the next person, but I try not showing it. 

First visit, gave them the benefit of the doubt. I've worked service industry, I understand people have bad days. 

Second visit, same thing. If you have an additional 20 minutes to kill, get a coffee here. Watch as they make you feel awkward by doing what they can to avoid eye contact, while making you feel like you're an inconvenience. 

I don't expect much; maybe I'm picky, but ill stick to trouble coffee.
author: Brad W.

description:
This place makes my favorite latte in the world. Yes THE WORLD!

The butterscotch latte is heaven in a cup. It's not overly sweet and almost has a salty hint to it. It's weird but it really works. Even my bf who doesn't really drink coffee gets one every time we stop by.  For some reason it tastes better hot than it does iced. The butterscotchy flavor somehow gets lost in the cold latte. Luckily since this part of SF is usually cool, I can always opt for the hot one.

There is very limited seating inside and they have a couple of benches outside.

The service is always friendly and their bathroom is always clean :)
author: Gina G.

description:
Quaint coffee shop with interesting knick-knacks and gourmet mochas. It was my kind of mocha, not too sweet and not too bitter. My sister, on the other hand, has sweeter taste buds and would prefer a sweeter mocha -- preferably from The Beanery on Irving and 9th. Pastries are not what you would find in an ordinary, commercialized coffee shop, but a combination of the norm and the new.

Highly recommended for intimate/dog-walking/first date kind of dates.
author: Joanne K.

description: Came here for a coffee break and ordered a small latte. The latte was made well, no complaints there. They do have decaf, just in case you're wondering. I wanted to order the Spanish chicken empanada, and they ran out :( I ordered the spinach and feta empanada instead- it was just aight. Was surprised with the total cost of 2lattes and 1 empanada, but figured that I was paying extra for the quality of the coffee itself. Still, expect to pay a bit more than you usually do elsewhere. If my memory serves me right, there were 2 or 3 very small tables and a bench- definitely would not recommend for groups. The guy that took my order wasn't too pleasant, but the lady who made my latte was actually very polite. Will probably come back to try the butterscotch latte that everyone has been talkin about.
author: Christine G.

description: I happened to walk by Hollow on my way to get a root canal (yay), and I couldn't be happier that I found this gem! The second I walked in, wow, I felt like I was transported to a different time. Music was playing from the 1920's, decor was so quaint and beautiful. And my drink, vanilla bean latte, was delicious!!! Can't wait to come back and try more drinks and pastries!
author: Suzanna F.

description: Hollow has been a beneficiary of climate change. The Sunset district can be blustery, but the generally sunny weather lately makes Hollow a must-try. The coffee drinks are very well made, and the decor is rustic and charming.
author: Thirsty C.

description:
Their coffee is great, my boyfriend is a coffee fanatic and I especially try the vanilla bean latte because its not syrup-y sweet but a total treat.

HOWEVER...We have been here 3 times now since I live close by, and every time without fail, have been treated incredibly rudely.
 
1 - The first time we were there it was only my boyfriend and I. We waited about 10 minutes for our drinks - one latte and one iced coffee. Luckily there are lots of little hipster things to look at.
2 - The second time, iced coffee for my bf, and all I wanted was water. The barista rolled her eyes at me, then quite forcefully put down a mason jar of water.
3 - The third time we both ordered iced coffees and since I was a bit hungry, considered trying their vanilla bean marshmallow. The entire interaction went like this "Two iced coffees please and.., one marshmallow" (2 seconds later after I notice how large these marshmallows are ) "actually, just the coffee" (then my boyfriend says TO ME: "I'll share it with you, go ahead and get it" to which the barista responds with such attitude "What's it going to be?!" (We were alone, no other patrons waiting...) 

There are other delicious, much friendlier, spots in the area to start your day.
author: Alina K.

description:
Good place for coffee if you're walking around golden gate park, very small storefront but nicely lit inside and has a restroom if needed. Very friendly and patient staff that helped us with our choices and has an updated register that I can sign on and get receipt by email which I loved.

We got a latte and a butterscotch latte, both completely met our needs on taste and included that design that we all come to love in a latte and gave us that much needed energy boost after walking almost 10 miles that day.

There is more seating around the corner from the register that I didn't see till I got up to use the restroom but it looked cozy.

The staff was so nice to let us stay a couple minutes over the open time while they were cleaning/closing up to finish our coffee and rest our legs before we departed again.

There is a drink there called the titanic, I wonder how big it is haha :P
author: Chase S.

description:
This place has tasty coffee though the sizes are very small for the price imo, but that doesn't bother me as much as this smarmy, rude, hipster guy who was working there 1 morning when I came in. He was sooo rude to me, that I will NEVER EVER EVER be in again! 

At least I see from other reviews that its not just me, and that other people have had the same experiences. I don't want to get into the details of my encounter because I don't feel like reliving again but lets just say, I have never been treated that way in any sort of cafe or restaurant in my life. Completely rude, condescending, treating me like I was the stupidest person on earth for asking what the difference was between their 2 different Mocha drinks. Anyway whatever... it is what it is... Even though its a nice, local, neighborhood business, they need to check their employees before they go out of business!
author: David S.

description:
Great place to chat with friends. The Latte is okay. I prefer more smooth, creamy milk of Latte. The cookie is okay as well. Although it was a small place, but I really like the feeling and decoration in Hollow. And the cake - which I forgot the name- was delicious.
Overall, it's a wonderful place that I have a great time with a friend!
author: Chloé C.

description: Came here during a cafe hopping adventure and this was my favorite spot! It's small and quaint when you first step in--it feels very warm and inviting! The butterscotch latte was amazing! They had all these baked goods, but I didn't try them. The decor was so whimsical and cute. There's also a lot more seating in the back. The staff is also super friendly and very helpful!
author: Alison M.

description: Coffee is not bad, but the service is horrible. Went there to get a coffee to go early this morning, there are 3 workers at the counter. I was the only customer there trying to order something, stood there for 5 minutes, no body bother to acknowledge me or take my order. One of the Caucasian lady, I think she might be the owner or manager looked at me twice and did not acknowledge nor offered to take my order. The facial expression is as if her coffee shop is too good for me. There was another Hispanic lady who works there standing further away saw that but was busy making coffee, finally offered to take my order. At first I was thinking to myself, maybe that lady is just having a bad day and I should just let it go. But as I was waiting for my coffee, there was another Caucasian lady came in to order something. That manger/ owner was already welcoming her making conversation and taking her order within 15 seconds. Wow, what a different! Maybe my kind is indeed not welcome there. Definitely would not expect that in San Francisco... let alone my neighborhood.
author: Andy L.

description: Coffee was alright, I found more grounds in the bottom of my cup than I am used to. I like the design of the place but it gives you a feeling that it has alot going on with all the various chocolate and other things for sale and the light bulbs placed laying down on the shelves for ambient lighting (waste of electricity). Nothing out of this world or worth the drive for me.
author: Yosof R.

description: Nice people, cozy atmosphere.  They let me bring my baby's stroller in.  Ordered an espresso, it was bad.  A shot cup is pretty tiny, it was barely half filled.  I think they over extracted so my espresso was extremely sour.  Can't say I will go back because I was just there to hang with a friend, so I'm just rating the espresso.
author: Victor H.

description:
Highly recommend for their home made toffee caramel latte and vanilla bean latte. 
Toffee caramel latte, not too sweet but full of toffee deliciousness! 
Vanilla bean is light and aromatically wonderful. Waaaaayyyy better than typical vanilla latte with vanilla syrup. 

Also love their small goods, especially Tokyo Milk perfume. Makes me smell sexy, and beautiful!
author: JustinE Y.

description:
Got a butterscotch latte and a Guinness cupcake. Latte had a lot of butterscotch flavor, but it was lukewarm!!! Also a bit sweet for my liking, but I should add that I like my coffee dark roasted and very strong. I think they use Ritual Coffee. I did get some fancy latte art, so I SUPPOSE that didn't ruin the TOTAL experience... because we all know the disappointment of paying an arm and a leg for coffee and not getting latte art, right? :P

Tiny tiny place, but they have these amazing tables that turn so you can adjust the height. LOVE the industrial design of that. Really charming, would come again and try a different drink.
author: Ann L.

description: Cannot plan a great day in the city without looking for a unique little coffee shop to start the day. My boyfriend and I found this little gem. It is easy to miss, so you'll have to look out. But this quaint, and charming place is worth it. From its rustic décor, to its tasty caffeinated beverages, this café is hipster heaven.
author: Brittany S.

description: A little coffee cafe with a lot of character. Friendly and genuine people make delicious lattes and empanadas here. Their wide variety of pastries are delicious as well.
author: Chad B.

description: This place is adorable. Their drinks and food are amazing. Seating is a bit uncomfortable but overall I love this place. Oh yeah, should mention there is NO wifi here in case you're looking for that. It's a great place to read or catch up with some friends.
author: Lauren D.

description: Great service and pretty good coffee. The Batista really takes his time to make your order. To insure quality, which I loved!
author: Aziz A.

description:
Okay, first thing... the coffee is great.  If you want a carefully crafted latte or cappuccino, this seems to be the only place in the neighborhood.

That being said, the service was not good.  The barista didn't acknowledge our presence for several minutes even though were were the only two in the cafe.  (He was fixing a drink for some one waiting outside.)  We just sat there awkwardly wondering if we should stay or go.

The drinks were good, but there is very little space in the shop so it was no good for sitting and hanging out.  The service is slow, so a line formed quickly, degrading the overall cafe experience.

The place is full of hipster charm, so at least we got to check out the interesting (but overpriced) soaps, scents, and lotions while we were waiting.
author: Lia C.

description: Lovely little place. Very cozy with friendly staff. Coffee was pretty good as well!
author: Ehsan N.

description:
I came here and ordered a small butterscotch latte. 4 things that sucked:
1. Didn't taste like butterscotch
2. Their 'small size' is EXTREMELY small
3. Was way overpriced for such a bad drink. 
4. Not-so-nice workers

Won't be back..no matter how much those homemade marshmallows tempt me.
author: Brooke F.

description: Hands down best cappaccino in the city. Atmosphere isn't clouding my espresso evaluation, though the interior design is pretty enough to warrant individual consideration. Espresso, 5 stars for being bold, rich and smooth. Atmosphere, 5 stars for being quaint, airy, and having adorable tables for two. Staff, 5 stars for being skilled, knowledgable and friendly.
author: Sonya I.

description: I've been passing by this place for nearly two years and have never had a minute to stop in, until recently.  It's a tiny (super tiny) little shop that serves up pretty delish coffee and empanadas.  I thought it was a little pricey for a drink where there wasn't much room to sit down and enjoy it.  There are a few small tables with a handful of chairs.
author: Cass H.

description:
Everything about this tiny cafe is cool...except for the coffee beans they use. Aside for my preference for anything but Ritual Coffee, I enjoyed finding this hole in the wall and all the trinkets inside. 

The whole space is big enough to comfortably accomodate 6-8 people maybe, and there's only one person working there. All the walls are lined with shelves with items for sale. It's the kind of stuff that would make for good gifts not easily found elsewhere. They also have pastries for sale and empanadas too!! How random! 

If you can even find this place, do check it out!
__
Dec '11 Health Score - 100!
author: Dennis L.

description: This is such a cute hipster coffee shop. The ambiance was cozy and the coffee was delicious! I ordered the vanilla bean latte and it was fabulous. The latte wasn't too sweet and was made just right. And the foam art was beautiful. I will definitely come back here to try the Titanic II latte because it looks divine. And the service was good as well as the pricing.
author: Amanda D.

description: Spiced green tea latte is delicious. Really like the heart art they put on our drinks. Small vintage like cafe with one person barista/cashier. Hubby got coffee. Coffee beans were grinded when ordered, measured with scale, then hot water pour over. Really good coffee. Mom's cappuccino was great too. Seems like anything you order here would taste great. Since it's a small place not ideal for hanging out but order to go.
author: Beverly N.

description: It's a hole in the wall but you can smell the coffee almost a block away. We got the 32 blackbirds mocha and the butterscotch. The mocha was nicely chocolatey but the latte could have a bit more butterscotch. The best part was the chocolate cupcake. Just the right amount of sweetness. If I lived around here, this would definitely be my to go place.
author: Rangoli A.

description: Super cute very intimate coffee and tea house.  Worth the wait for a fantastic coffee drink.   House made syrups. Visit this small style big flavor coffee house.
author: J R.

description: I really, really, REALLY want to love this place. The shop itself is super adorable. The coffee is good. The snacks are delicious. But my god, the service is awful.  They're so effing RUDE. I've been a bunch of times and I keep going back, hoping that it's just that one barista or just a busy day or something.. But pretty much every time I've been there, they're just so freaking rude. Today, I ordered a drink and two snacks. They gave me the snacks (I asked for "here" and they gave me them to go), served the people who came in after me, and (after about 15 minutes) the cashier gave me a super annoyed look and said "What are you waiting for?". Like, probably the thing I ordered and paid for....   And the most annoying thing about it all is that they aren't rude to everybody. I guess I'm just not the right "type" of person they want sitting in their shop. So, unless you're a mega-hipster who's accepted by other mega-hipsters, don't go here.
author: Melissa S.

description: Very cute place and the service is very friendly! I got a matcha latte and a spinach empanada which were both good. The matcha latte wasn't too sweet- just right. There's extra tables in the back. It's a little dark but I wasn't bothered by it. Nicely decorated and clean
author: Kim V.

description: I'm pretty sure this is a garage...turned into the cutest little coffee shop. Love the feel...wood decor, metal plates, two tables. Adorable.
author: Sawsan D.

description:
A tiny, hip coffee shop. Like, really hip. There's a table for two, a table for three, and a bench along the wall that can seat 4. Now that I think about it, there was also a striped stool between the bench and the Barista.

So there's seating for parties of 1, 2, 3, and 4. Clever?

Given the intimacy of the shop, the barista is someone you'll probably get to know as you become a regular. She has an amazing way of putting you at ease. I can't imagine her yelling :D 

When I asked her to dump ice in my hot black tea (I wanted an iced tea but they don't cold brew) she told me it wouldn't be good in that wry, impish sorta way that just made me have to have it*.

For those attracted by the glitter, there are all sorts of slick doodads for sale -- artisanal soap, rustic wood-and-steel wine openers, copper salt shakers, etc. I'll probably buy some for my apartment, but I think the intention is to signal quality.

As a side note, after my friend tasted his Vanilla Bean Latte, he let me know that this was his FIRST TIME DRINKING COFFEE EVER**. I couldn't believe it at first, but he explained to me that coffee is completely avoidable -- there's no peer pressure in college (unlike, say, alcohol) because by ubiquity (it's a completely unregulated drug) we all assume everyone has tried it already, and you can easily sidestep with a tea or a cocoa at a cafe. So there it is.

Four stars for intimacy, service, and hipness.

--------

*It wasn't bad, and I would get it again. My buddy and I decided to call it Revelation 3:16. For context, his parents are from Texas and mine are from the Midwest. I'm not sure if Bible-thumping is quite the phrase at least from a literal sense: they used it as a book, not a prop.***

**Unwittingly, it seems. He thought the vanilla bean was supplanting the coffee bean, which is reasonable.

***Although they are ministers, so from a figurative sense this would work. That's a discussion for another day. I'm not sure if this note even deserves its own indirection, since it is so closely related to the parent and hardly any more parenthetical than the original. In fact, it doesn't deserve it's own indirection, and I'm sorry for writing it this way.**** There is such thing as bad style. Quality.

****I once got in trouble in Jr. High for using footnotes (like, for using them at all)  My teacher may have been under the impression that giving parenthetical thoughts a platform steals the limelight, and leads to general discursion, although what _isn't_ discursion, i.e. so why stop at door #1? This is why I was never a straight-A student, but thankfully my parents were more interested in my personal salvation than my report card, which makes you really stop and think about what this whole thing at a pretty young age. In the words of Ice Cube from 21 Jump Street: "Stop f**king with Korean Jesus! He ain't got time for your problems!" A "C" in writing really pales compared to the "bigger" questions in life. But without writing, how will we organize our thoughts around these questions? Bad example. Okay okay I'm done.
author: Christophe C.

description: A nice, cozy little place for coffee. Their mocha and hot chocolate are exemplary, as are their cookies (all of their cookies!). The ambiance of the shop is rustic and casual and even though there isn't a ton of space, the interior is worth enjoying. Also not too intimidating for non-espresso aficionados. The latte art is also very tasteful. Stop by if you're in the area, it's well worth paying a visit!
author: Wesley K.

description:
Super cute. If you're looking for more than just coffee and pastries, visit Hollow- there are endless trinkets, soaps and small home goods to keep you occupied while you wait for your drink. It's a good thing there are so many trinkets, because the only reason I knocked a star was for the wait- two large coffees took about 10 minutes. Sure, it's french press, but not exactly a "grab your coffee and go" experience. 

We ate our pastries while we waited, bought two amazing-smelling soaps and eyed the magnifying classes, bear bottle openers, perfumes, salt and pepper shakers and more. Head on over if you're ever in the Inner Sunset.
author: Kristin F.

description:
Food: Very very good argentinean empanadas, great iced americano :)
(they also have muffins and other cool stuff, but didn't try them -looked good tho)


It's a small little place, but the ambiance is amazing, quite unexpected, and the person who was running the show was incredibly nice and amicable

If you are in the area and you are up for a nice treat, this is definitely the place you want to go to

Extra: the place also sells a ménage of vintage house and kitchen artifacts -handmade soaps, plates, letter openers, small stone vintage cupids, etc. it's a fun place!!
author: Gerardo C.

description: Super cute and cosy little coffee shop! I got a matcha latte, it was really delicious! The service was great, I will definitely come back!
author: Looblue L.

description: Adorable little nook of a coffee shop with cute trinkets galore. Coffee was yummy and I wanted to buy everything from the gold scissors to the cool metal straws (and I did). I like that the location feels out of the way from the hustle and bustle of the city. Feels like you are happening upon a hidden gem that not everyone has already discovered.
author: Andrea F.

description:
The Good. The Bad. And the ugly.

Good - coffee.
Bad - because i love their salted caramels.
Ugly - the parking situation on the weekends
author: Kristen C.

description: I have been here several times when I was in this area.I had tried vanilla bean latte, butterscotch latte and mocha, and they are all good. Today I stopped by and grabbed a butterscotch latte. The moment I got it, sipped it, and drank it all in a short time. The latte was totally beyond my expectation, a craftsman's work.
author: Mei-hsuan C.

description: I got some weird vibes from this place. We walked in and weren't acknowledged by any of the baristas while we stood at the register. Okay fine, it takes me a few minutes to look over the menu anyway. Eventually more people stop in and a line starts to form before the barista/cashier starts to take orders. Clearly, I'm the first in line directly in front of the register but she started speaking to the person behind me....?! So I had to butt in to place my order... Which took them about 10 minutes to make (and there were 3 baristas) Womp womp womp :(
author: Lily Z.

description:
I teach near hollow and as soon as I started I realized that this place would soothe all my high school addled nerves and be the highlight of each morning. To start, the coffee is great. The espresso shots are consistently perfect and smooth while the cold brewed iced coffee is a delicate dance of chocolatey deliciousness. The space is small, but I don't think a coffee shop owes it to its customers to be large. When I get a table I feel like I scored, and when I don't, i just go back to my classroom.

The objects for sale are all out of my price range but I like to look and dream that someday I may buy every slingshot, camping mug, and herb infused soap that my eyes fall upon. I'm a sucker for beautiful things and this place has many of them. It really is excellently curated. 

Now the best part, the baristas. It seems some folks have found them unfriendly  which I'm truthfully kind of shocked by. They are, in fact , quite friendly, just not in an insincere corporate kind of way. They crack jokes, they're sarcastic, they're all attractive. Jesus Christ what more do you want people?

Annnnnnyway. A ++ for hollow. 
Thanks for always making my day.
author: Lacy D.

description: Just went here the other day, nothing really special besides the fact it's just a small somewhat artisian coffee place with rustic wood decor etc. First off, kind of pricey considering when I checked Yelp it has a one dollar sign and their cups come in small portions. I went in wanting to try the Titanic II but seeing as the price was $8.50 (could just get lunch for that price) I opted for the butterscotch latte. And though I wasn't expecting it to be an overwhelming sweet caramel taste it honestly tasted like steamed milk, could barely taste the butterscotch and even had my friend try it to double check. My friend got just a regular French press which wasn't anything extraordinary that you couldn't make in your own kitchen. So for $4 and a "small" which was essentially the size of a water cup, I wont be coming back. Also added to the fact that this place is really small I felt uncomfortable just standing there feeling like I had no where to stand.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Nearly the best coffee I have ever had in my life. PERIOD.

AND O-M-FREAKING-G the Cinnamon roll biscuit IS INGENIOUS. If you like salty-sweet delicious DO IT. Or if you like biscuits DO IT. Or if you like cinnamon buns DO IT.

Then all the trinkets scattered around the store are just cute and would make excellent gifts. Cute artisan items at a decent price what is not to love?

Good service which is rare (in my experience) when it comes to artisan coffee at least in the south bay. Buncha grumpsters. Maybe stop drinking so much espresso and get some sleep yo!

Decorum is warm and inviting your surrounded by the interesting knick-knacks for sale. A table or two inside which isn't surprising given the smallness. Beware the bathroom all the way in the back is not so inviting and very very claustrophobic. However it is clean-ish and functional.

Hipster coffee always makes for the best coffee! Especially in places you least expect.
author: Christine G.

description:
I had been wanting to try this adorable place for a long time. I had a free day, so I took the opportunity to go and have something delicious.

Walking in, it's small. Like, VERY small. Maybe two tables and a bench of seating room. They had some decent business that day so there was nowhere to sit.

I ordered a vanilla latte and a Guinness beer cupcake. I was disappointed when the lovely lady making drinks AND ringing up customers (short-staffed?) told me they were out of vanilla. Out of vanilla at 10 am? What?

I sucked it up and decided to go for the famed butterscotch latte. I squeeze myself onto a bench and wait for my latte, awkwardly holding a plate with my cupcake on it. Seeing as I couldn't set the plate down anywhere, I scarfed it down before I had the chance to get my drink. It was absolutely divine, I must say.

The same woman who was making the drinks AND ringing people up came to me with my drink. I excitedly take my first sip... and no butterscotch. Not even a hint. 

Overall, the latte was meh, the seating was unfortunate, and the cupcake was BOMB. 

Might come back when it's less crowded and cross my fingers for vanilla.
author: Marisa H.

description: The baristas are SO SO LOUD that I get distracted so easily every minute. I don't think that they realise their NOISE pollutes the amazing atmosphere in the cafe.
author: Campbell L.

description: You know it's sad when you have such a passion for all things coffee and try and support smaller boutique coffee shops to help promote the bettering of coffee culture throughout the world. And your barista makes snarky and rude comments about your drink choices while you are still around. I understand you have your own personal taste and preferences . But sometimes it's mindful to consider customers especially those who travel far and wide in pursuit of the best cup around . Unfortunately I won't be returning as I did not feel welcome in what otherwise I would call a beautiful establishment. Something to think about before judging others . Enjoy and saving a star because the cashier had a wonderful smile
author: Thedips D.

description:
Finding Hollow made my day. It's a tiny green box of amazing gadgets, gizmo's, gifts, pastries, empanadas, & coffee.

The decor and merch are thoughtfully designed, and makes waiting for my iced americano a bit like alice in wonderland time (dreamy, whimsical, fun....). 

This is a spot that I will reserve to take very special friends and out of town guests.
author: Jocelyn B.

description: Cute little cafe with strong coffee. Their lattes are the best! It's not a Starbucks, meaning, their coffee prep takes time. It's definitely an art when they make it.
author: Jamie C.

description:
The girl making the coffee was very friendly and helpful, which was much appreciated. We tried the Butterscotch Latté and Ghirardelli Mocha. Both were drinks were good, but had had a very similar taste. They weren't too sweet, just the right amount, and had a sweeter foam.
The place itself had a very nice vibe, kind of a hole-in-the-wall sort of place. I also appreciated the pretty foam design, worth taking a picture!
author: Mila S.

description:
Really adorable little itty bitty café-shop with elaborate (and elaborately priced) coffee drinks.
It's not the easiest to get to, but you'll know when you've arrived! Look for their hand painted sign.
About maybe 2.5 tables. 
Come for a fancy schmancy, delicious drink and stay for the "oh my goodness, so cute!" items for sale.
author: Rachel D.

description: Cute little coffee shop that serve Ritual coffee in the inner sunset. If you're a hipster, this is the place to be in this hood. Otherwise there's a Starbucks down the road...
author: Melanie N.

description: Adorable place. Girlfriend and i got the green matcha and americano. Beautiful presentation and taste was even better. Super friendly barista. Highly recommend for anybody who wants a quaint getaway
author: joyce w.

description:
Hollow has been on my list of "places to try" for some time now.  Since I'm only living in SF for a few more weeks, I made sure to stop by.  The place itself is really tiny, so don't plan on meeting a huge group of friends here.  But if you just want a cozy, quieter place to catch up with one friend, this may be the place.  

The menu seems a bit hidden if you're never been before, it's behind the counter and against the back wall.  They have pretty standard coffee house offerings, and I went with one of my favorites- the vanilla latte.  I chose a small and it cost $3.75.  It definitely is on the smaller side, but it's tasty and I prefer quality over quantity.  The drink was not the best vanilla latte that I've had, but definitely worth trying.  On the menu, it says "house made," so I think that means that they make the vanilla syrup/flavoring there (?).  I saw lots of little black specks in the latte, so I'm assuming that it was vanilla.  The latte was on the sweeter side, so even if you don't drink coffee or like coffee that much, I think the drink is pretty good.  I appreciate the attention to detail and hand-crafted-ness of the drink.  Plus, the barista made a pretty foam art piece on top.  Barista was not overly talkative, but he was very nice.

While you're waiting for the drink to be made, there is plenty to look at as well.  Soaps, candles, stationary, wine openers, lighting fixtures- there's a little bit of everything.  The store is small, but they do have a lot in there.  There are a couple of tables inside, but it was a nice day so I chose to sit at the one table outside of the shop. 

P.S.  They have an assortment of baked sweets and empenadas as well.
author: Samantha L.

description:
This nice little coffee shop in the Inner Sunset with it's rustic vibe and tasty treats is not to miss. The shop always had a relaxed atmosphere with wonderful music, nice lighting and caring staff. 

Their espressos, lates, machiatos and other drinks are not rushed and made with care. Every drink is velvety and never underdone or bitter. 

The shop also has a great charm to it with fantastic gourmet chocolates and little trinkets (from metal straws to soaps and animal themed salt &  pepper shakers). 

This is a great place to relax, get a gift or enjoy some fine coffee.
author: Jack S.

description:
Another in my continuing series of West Portal & nearby-ish reviews...

Fantastic coffee, and one of the *very* few (only?!) anywhere close to me in the Sunset / West Portal that's worth going to (yes, even compared to Trouble - which has fantastic pastries but honestly, not great coffee, for all their eff-you spunkiness - and is in the middle of nowhere, on top of it). THANK GOD they exist, because I was getting a little depressed about having moved from SOMA's embarrassment-of-riches coffee district (Blue Bottle, Sightglass, etc.).
author: S G.

description: Delicious coffee and baked treats. I have yet to try the empanadas but they always have several yummy-sounding ones. The baristas are always friendly and efficient. The tiny shop has just 3 little tables so hanging out isn't always an option. Hollow also has really neat gifts and artisanal goodies for sale
author: Abby G.

description:
Decent product, if a bit overpriced, and a good atmosphere. People however, knocked down my rating. Went a while ago simply looking for a place to do some work. Nicely asked if they have Wi-Fi and was told they don't (not a problem, I admire that they don't). Once we went outside I heard the staff and a customer talking rudely about us (and making very broad judgements) because we were looking for Wi-Fi.

Decor and product is good but staff could use a little less pretension.
author: Bryant O.

description: Five stars minus one for the service. Pretty good service until I simply asked if the prepackaged waffle on the counter would be something my 3 year old son might like. The response I got was "I wouldn't know your son's taste". A simple I don't know or kids usually like them etc. would have been fine but that response wasn't what I needed.
author: Royce R.

description: This place is adorable! It was a little crowded when we went, but it was absolutely worth it. Grabbed the matcha green tea latte and a spanish chicken empanada and it was the perfect afternoon snack.
author: Leah R.

description: Charming, high-quality, very unique coffee shop with lots of fun trinkets to peruse/purchase to boot! Haven't tried any of their baked treats, but all look amazing.
author: Elena K.

description:
This place is definitely cute from the outside, but super small inside. Coffee was good, but took fooorreevver to make. The baked goods looked amazing, though we didn't try any. My main beef with this place was how unfriendly the staff was. No greeting when we walked in (even though it was empty except for one person), and I literally stood at the counter for probably a full minute until the guy working there who was 2 feet from my face even acknowledged my presence. I live in the area and am just not used to this in the Sunset -- maybe in the Mission or something, but the Sunset is still a friendly neighborhood. 

Oh, and the prices for the sizes -- yikes!!
author: Lindsey L.

description:
WHY aren't there more of these in San Francisco.  Delicious baked goodies and artisan chocolates, really clever and beautiful little gifty housewares and Ritual coffee, all in a comfy, teeny space that is somehow neither dusty nor cramped and all at a really reasonable price point.

Somebody used "hipster" to define it in an earlier review, which would be correct, were there also $10 stenciled gift cards here or $20 hand-sharpened pencils, or if they even made their prices higher, which it looks like they're actually making a point not to do. 

Hollow is charming without being precious, which you can only do if you genuinely care about the beauty of the things you buy. I'm a fan. yay..
author: Missy B.

description: I love my inner sunset and I love my coffee. This joint is the best of both worlds. Small, quaint, and makes a great cup of love. The quality is great and their sweets look tempting as well. Great neighborhood coffee house.
author: Michelle I.

description:
Ambiance:
This place is reminiscent of a fusion between a hobbit nook inside a Tolkien but only if those lil hobbits made houseware/perfume elements. It has a really lovely ambiance and the coffee was absurdly good. I mean it was just bananas! 

Types of Coffee:
Ritual coffee, artisan dark chocolate mochas, vanilla lattes in which you can actually see the beans...none of that sure, its vanilla....but then there's no beans and you're like you bullshitted me hard faux vanilla pushing monster!!!!!! No, none of that, this shiz is the real deal, real dealishous!!! 

People:
Everyone is really nice, anddd  has great turnaround on drinks even when there are a grip of people and one person behind the counter.

In Summation:
Hats off, hollow. Highly recommend!
author: Danielle T.

description: $7.75 for a supposedly Large artisan mocha. Large cup here is medium at best elsewhere. I actually asked twice "is this large?"  Mocha (artisan at that) was completely watered down and not creamy at all. I can understand not creamy since you can always add creamer yourself later, but watered down is just no at this price point. Coffee had no caffeine kick or that thick mocha feel to it. Absolute garbage. Save $8 and go elsewhere.
author: Mr C.

description:
Super cute and tiny! Delicious snacks, and tons of trinkets and odds and ends (for purchase!) that will keep your eye entertained while you wait for your order. I've never fancied myself a person who buys her perfume at her coffeehouse, but this place might just turn me into one.

Really great service. Happy to support this place. Wouldn't recommend coming here with the intention of camping out and doing work though.
author: Megan S.

description: I came here after reading this was one of the 10 most recommended coffee places in SF (oooh). I can now proudly say I have been to all 10. Oh man, SF knows how to do coffee right. There are only about 3 tables in this place (beware if you want to camp out for awhile). The coffee was honestly kinda just okay. It's the barista who deserves the 4th star for being super friendly and they sell a bunch of cute lil trinkets, too.
author: Mel G.

description: I really wanted to love this place. I loved the idea and the interior, however, the coffee was not that good. I tried the Vanilla Bean Latte with Vanilla Bean marshmallow and my friend had the Green Tea Matcha Latte. The presentation was superb, but I've had better coffee elsewhere.
author: Karina A.

description: This is one of the cutest little coffee shop I've ever seen. The design is very cozy and fits perfectly with the inner sunset. I came here around 11am so it was a bit crowded. I got the iced butterscotch latte and it was deliciousssss. It was perfect brewed and not too sweet. The staff here is also very mellow and pleasant.
author: Cara N.

description:
Ever go to a coffee shop for a cup of coffee and end up engaging the baristas in a debate about cruelty to slugs?  HAHAHAHHAA!  That was probably the most memorable experience here.  Aside from expecting it to take about 20 minutes for a drink at every visit, we walked in one empty day to the barista talking about how his floor at home has slugs in the mornings, and he's always stepping on them before he can reach the light switch.  I mentioned he could put salt around the perimeter of the room to keep them from coming in, and the cashier said that was a horrible idea since it would torture the slugs.  #Hipsters.  I tried to explain that you don't pour it ON the slugs, but she just kept saying that I was mean and horrible.  

For being a coffee spot, the staff here are really judgMENTAL.  She once told Sandra that Robert was too big for a stroller.  He wasn't even 2 yet, and they walked 8 blocks to get there.  

The location is literally a hole in the wall and can hold about 9 people comfortably.  They have various knick knacks along the walls for sale, most of them have nothing to do with coffee.  

The coffee is good, but to avoid dealing with the staff, I'd rather walk down to Drip'd.
author: ROB L.

description: This is our spot for the last 6+ month. A cool little neighborhood place with good people and great coffee!
author: Reut D.

description: I came here one morning with WFH and the pictures on Yelp is definitely deceiving.  This place is so small, its definitely easy to miss.  Although the cappuccino was good, the cookie was small and not worth the price ($1-2), and the waffle is prepackaged with disgustingly large pieces of sugar rocks hidden in them.  Would I come back?  Why?
author: Dean W.

description: This coffee place has a great feel to it: very small and rustic. The service was good, the people were nice, and the latte and coffee were both done well. The downside is that there is no outdoor seating yet, but there are a few small tables inside.
author: Nate R.

description:
After walking around Irving, I noticed this shop for it's bright green store front. Although it was getting too late for coffee, my boyfriend and I decided to try this place out.

I had my first Cortado here while he had a cup of coffee. It would be a great place to sit down with a friend or read a book. So I went here again a week later with two friends. 

This time there was only one barista on duty so drinks took a while but we honestly did not mind. I had a cappuccino and my two friends had tea. The tea sets were really cute except one tea kettle had a nice ceramic strainer while the other looked similar to a sink's strainer.

Other than that, great little cafe. I do want to visit this place again to try more of their drinks and possibly buy some of their cute merchandise.
author: Erin A.

description: How adorable is this coffee shop? I love that they pour Ritual coffee and their empanadas are delicious. Lady behind the counter was very friendly.
author: Megan E.

description: Get the vanilla bean latte, chocolate croissant and make sure you take a whiff of the Tokyo Milk Dark perfumes, they're spellbinding! The Titanic is awesome and the most unique coffee drink I've ever had! But make sure you do not take it to go and have someone to share it with. It is beyond rich!
author: Maggie D.

description: Really.good.stuff.  Great staff but the price of a cortado seems a bit high....which is why I don't go every single day.  Otherwise I would.
author: Mel M.

description: Definitely one of, if not my favorite coffee spot in SF. Unless you're familiar with the Inner Sunset, you may likely miss it. Very tiny and quaint almost Frodo-like, from the outside, and is no different from the inside where there's 2 small round tables and maybe 4 seats total. They also sell some very unique and interesting items aside from coffee that they've used for display. As for coffee, any of the lattes especially the butterscotch latte are good. The servings are smaller compared to other places which may seem expensive but they do put a lot of love and craft into them.
author: Neil I.

description:
One word to describe this place: charming.

From the outside, Hollow is a tiny bright green building nestled between other small buildings. On the inside, it somehow seems even tinier (but in a good way, like cozy).

This is the sort of coffee shop that I have sorely missed living in LA. The barista spends a lengthy amount of time preparing a beautiful little cup of coffee, which you can sip while sitting at one of three little wooden tables.

They also sell baked goods and pastries, as well as eclectic little knick knacks and an assortment of yummy smelling TokyoMilk products. 

I don't know exactly why, but everything in this coffee shop just works. It's quirky and mellow and beautiful and one of the biggest reasons why I wish I lived in San Francisco.
author: Ran J.

description:
Checked this out with a friend today. 

Mushroom Gorgonzola empanada was delicious.  Large ritual latte was perfect.

Carved wooden serving plates, Restoration Hardware inspired light fixtures and rustic wooden furnishings throughout.  Menus displayed on re-purposed vintage window panes.  Unique fragrances and other little treasures displayed on virtually every surface (available for purchase).  

The two guys behind the counter were handsome and affable frothing machines. 

Loved this place.  You probably will, too.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Without a doubt the cutest little coffee shop I have ever laid eyes upon! Everything about this place just screams coziness and warmth-it's such an awesome cafe. First of all the service-perfect. The food-superb. The drinks-delicious. And lastly the gifts-wow...I want to buy everything. Yup, pretty much I want to move in to this place. 
With that out of the way, I ordered the gingerbread and the butterscotch latte-definitely recommend the butterscotch one, it's very frothy and sweet. I also got the oatmeal cake-wow, it makes my mouth water just thinking about it. Enough said. Then the Guinness cupcakes were also very yummy. This was just my first time here, and hopefully my next time in sf, I will be able to come here again.
author: Chloe R.

description: I can't say good enough things about the coffee and the staff here, they're both consistent in being awesome.
author: D W.

description: Cute and charming little cafe. Excellent lattes and baked goods. Been here 3 times, all were great experiences. Would recommend all my friends.
author: Han N.

description: This place came highly recommended. It's super cute and the staff is super nice, and the latte was super good. It deserves 5 super stars but service was super slow. I felt bad for the solo barista with the line growing out the door. It wasn't so much my impatience but how awkwardly silent it was as everyone kept looking to the front of the line to see what was taking so long. One of the guests in front of me finished her drink before her friend's was done being made.
author: Jeff B.

description:
I didn't really believe in love at first sight... especially with a coffee shop.  

I was getting food at San Tung down the street and they told me it was a 25 minute wait for takeout.  So I Yelped coffee places and found this one.  I'm so glad I chose to walk the extra few blocks.  Hollow is easily one of the most amazing places I've ever been to in San Francisco.  From its cozy decor to its old-fashioned gifts, I almost forgot that I was in the US.  

Don't get me wrong, it is TINY.  There's about three small tables crammed in near the door, but on a lazy Thursday afternoon there were only two other customers sitting there.  The latte I got was amazing, and even better when sipped with the sunlight streaming inside the windows.  When "Can't Take My Eyes Off You" came on, I was done.  

Hollow, you complete me.
author: J X.

description: Small but very live cafe with a positive vibe and delicious coffees.
author: Hamed B.

description: We stopped in here after some shopping to grab a quick coffee and I fell in love with this place. The cappuccino I had was great, but the random gifts they have inside are worth coming here to buy even if you're not a coffee fan. I saw really cool bottle openers, cheese knives, perfumes, coasters and candles. All unique and I doubt even the pickiest person would be stoked on recieving any thing from here. The decor is all wood and very cozy. Come check it out!
author: Nikki H.

description: Have been here twice now. Expertly made coffee creations. Really love the homemade butterscotch sauce latte. Truly divine. Have a few baked good options. Very limited seating. I feel like something is missing and wasn't a fan of the vanilla bean latte. Tasted a little like bubble gum. Stick with the butterscotch latte or French hot chocolate, you won't be sorry.
author: Victoria O.

description: This is the cutest cafe and I feel so very fortunate to have it in the neighborhood. It's a nice quiet spot to meet a friend for some coffee or to cozy up with a book. I always like to look through the well-edited selection of giftable trinkets they have. They've got a nice selection of cafe drinks as well as local made pastries and baked goods. One day I'm going to have to try the empanadas. The hot chocolate is delicious.
author: Alice H.

description:
This place has the best coffee I've ever had. The Americano is to die for. Warning: if you're coming in to get drip coffee, go somewhere else. They only do espresso drinks. I'm not sure how they make the best coffee in the entire universe, but there you have it. Coffee always depends on how it's prepared, and these baristas know exactly what they're doing.

The inside is very rustic with a French feel. I love to sit at one of the two tables and just take in the ambiance of Hollow. It's like you step into a different world when you enter here. It's akin to stepping inside a Hobbit hole to have coffee or tea with Bilbo Baggins himself. The nic-nacs that they sell are unique and beautiful, but over-priced.

Highly recommended.
author: Michael S.

description: They have the BEST espresso drinks. Four barrel coffee, hand pulled shots and milk steamed to order. They know what they are doing, but it takes time. Not the place to go if you are in a rush. I love the cortado, it's my new favorite. Their lattes are good too. This place is tiny and gets full real fast, but they have extra seating in the back.
author: Michalle R.

description: This place is officially my new favorite place to get coffee. They serve rituals coffee! I got the vanilla bean latte, butterscotch latte and their vanilla bean homemade marshmallows. All good! The marshmallow's have a different texture than the store-bought Jett Puffs I'm use to having. Theres even little vanilla bean specks in it. I LOVED the vanilla bean latte. It wasn't too bitter, not too strong and not too sweet either. None of that Starbucks crap. Super creamy. Total came out to $9.50 which is decent. The coffee shop itself is pretty small but has a wooden-cozy interior. I didn't get to try the beer cupcake everyone has been raving about, but that's just my excuse for coming back!
author: Laura T.

description: A very cozy coffee shop with nice wooden decorations.. Recently found out there is a small back room that is super cute! Absolutely love their coffee and adorable coffee designs! Super friendly and sociable staff, definitely recommend this place!
author: Soha H.

description:
Good taste.

You'll come for the excellent Ritual Coffee. Current blend was the Stickball from El Salvador/Guatamala. Hint of Meyer lemon, plum and caramel apple. Good taste.

You'll discover an impressive assortment of cookies, candies, fragrances and home accents. Also good taste.

Together they make for an excellent tasting experience.
author: Jason B.

description: I had a vanilla bean latte and it was amazing! The best latte ever!!! I can't wait to go back.
author: Hajuu D.

description: This place is super cute and reminds me a lot of East London. Very small and cozy, with hipstery appeal. My friends enjoyed their empanadas and chai lattes with almond milk. I found a limonata pellegrino  in the fridge in the back with the kombucha that hit the spot for a 75 degree February SF day :)
author: Eliza D.

description: I ordered the titanic II (over $8) and spinach empanada ($4.5?). It's awesome. The price is on the pricier side.  The place is cute, the service is great. Definitely come back here.
author: Zippi B.

description: This place is AMAZING! so many cute things inside, as well as tasty drinks. My sister took me here as a surprise. Went on a friday morning LOTS of parking. We got the titanic its this chocolatey mocha with a huge homemade vanilla bean marshmallow floating on top. The barista told us that they melt half of a chocolate bar into the mocha which is what makes it so rich. its $7 for the titanic which may sound steep but once you drink it you'll realize that its way worth every penny!!
author: Brittany S.

description:
This place is adorable! It's super tiny and it feels like you're in a fairy house or something. It has a miniature fountain, tons of little handmade soaps and things, and really cute pastry displays. It feels woodsy and homey, although it can be a bit drafty. 

The coffee was nothing special. I prefer a darker roast. I did have a chicken sausage empanada however, and it was pretty good. The crust was phenomenal! For what you get though, the food can be a bit pricey (I remember getting empanadas in Peru for about 50 cents...), especially when you consider that the location is nothing special.

I would definitely come here again.
author: Sonia J.

description: Good coffee and pastry. Place is a bit tight but great atmosphere and decoration. Definitely try out the marshmallow if possible!
author: J Y.

description:
Whenever we walk home after dinner, we would pass this little hole in the wall (literally); but since we don't eat dinner @ 4pm, we have never seen it open.  Finally, the Boyfriend paid a visit with a friend & said I have to check it out for myself.

The first time we visited, he got a Butterscotch latte that he didn't get last time.  It was not too sweet, slightly salty, kind of toasty, & just SO GOOD.  I got a Vanilla latte which took a lot of effort.  It wasn't very vanilla'y but it was definitely better than the artificial syrup flavor; it was too sweet for my taste though.

Since it was so delicious last time, we came back soon & the Boyfriend got the same thing with the addition of a Guinness cupcake.  The drink was delicious as ever but the cupcake tasted much like a plain chocolate cupcake.  I got an Artisan dark chocolate mocha which was good & was more like a drinking chocolate with coffee instead of coffee with milk & chocolate syrup.

This is a really small space with only a couple of tables so it's not the best spot for catching up with multiple friends.  But if you are into good, hand crafted coffee made with real ingredients, definitely come check this place out.  Oh, there are also cute trinkets for sale like sling shots & metal bending straws.
author: Karen S.

description: um! hello charm in SF! ok, this place makes me smile, talk quiet, and just fall in love with all that is good in the world. And you know whats super good? THIS PLACE!! From the teas that you can enjoy with a friend in a little cut tea pot, or a yummy coffee. This place is such a jewel. They have a one person worker here so don't think your coming to place where they are pumping out coffee super fast, think of a place where you wanna go to for a good cup after a good meal or to start off your weekend. They also have little gifts here. Like Tokyo Milk perfume, and really cute bottle openers, salt and pepper shakers...ect...
author: Holly L.

description:
Quality coffee, a bit on the higher end of my price range, but nevertheless exactly what I needed when it comes to my coffee-caffeine kick. The coffee has a wonderful flavor, with depth to it. If I were a solid black coffee or expresso drinker, I think I would be in heaven, but since I like my cream and milk - I go for the lattes. 

On the plus side, while you wait, there's so much to look at! Trinkets under the category "would I really buy this... oh wait but I really want it now!" - and basically things you don't need but really want! There's also really nice smelling soaps, candles and perfumes that would make nice gifts. It's so easy to walk out of this coffee shop spending $30 instead of the $4.

The only con is that the cup sizes weren't consistent for me. The first time I went, the server asked me what size, and I said Medium. He pulled out two cups and said those were the only sizes he carried. The second time I went, I ordered a latte again and they automatically assumed I wanted a small. I let it pass because "the smaller cup" was what I got last time -- and guess what? Yeah, the size that didn't exist last time suddenly appeared. At least the price was cheaper.
author: Christal Y.

description: Sorry really nice people but the coffee was really not good.... I had a mocha and I had to throw it away....I love Blue Bottle and the other local one I love is Andytown.
author: May F.

description:
The Inner Sunset's answer to Ladurée. Lots of gilding and ornamentation happening in a cozy wooded space, not to mention beautiful desserts housed under belljars.

The bulk of a visit to Hollow can be spent sampling their extensive stock of Tokyomilk fragrances and rifling through an impressive array of gifts and nice-to-haves. I'm reminded a bit of Paxton Gate - objects for sale are tactile, whimsical, and handmade.

Coffee and tea are great and you're spoilt for choice here. $4.50 for a cup of Pu-erh struck me as a bit overboard though. They'd do well to consider 2-serving pots of tea.

Barista I've encountered a couple times seemed less than thrilled to be occupying this particular hobbit hole.

Not a place for a laptop, and there's no wi-fi. A place for Proust, yes.
author: Jack G.

description: This place is truly a hidden gem. It is small but really retro. Server is excellent and the coffee is wonderful too.   Very nice small place to visit if you just want to stop by and grab a quick coffee.
author: Randy L.

description: This place is smaller than my kitchen, but they make great Cappuccinos!  They also sell a couple of premium chocolates there including Dandelion.  It's really small...don't blink as  you go by 16th and Irving.
author: Dennis M.

description: First time here and may I say it is awesome! I've never had anything other than Starbucks but this place is absolutely fantastic from the setting to the menu! I highly recommend it! It's affordable, friendly, and a nice spot to just sit down and have a great conversation among friends or to have time for yourself! I'll most definitely be coming back!
author: Shaniah M.

description:
Hollow is a small and very cute little coffee shop. I actually passed it the first time and had to drive back around, but was really excited when I saw how cute it was. They sell  cute, but expensive little knick knacks. 
The  employees could use a course in customer service. They were unpleasant and very dry, verging on being a little bit rude. It made me feel uncomfortable to be in such a small space with them. The girl broke a glass vase and I was getting sugar for my coffee, and pieces of it hit me in the leg (which didn't hurt me at all), and she gave me the driest, least genuine "sorry" I've ever heard. Like I said, it didn't hurt me, but I work in customer service and I would have at least sounded apologetic if I had done that. Furthermore, when my friend paid for his coffee she set the iPad to the side and didn't say anything to him, as he walked away she said, "do you want to sign this?!" ....Okay lady, you could've asked him, as the iPad was not placed in front of him. 
Onto the coffee: I ordered the Titanic. I asked her what was in it and she dryly said, "it's just a dark mocha" ...so I ordered it. It was $8 for the "large." Their "large" is probably the size of a small anywhere else. The titanic isn't terrible, but it's definitely not worth $8. 
They also leave some of their pastries out right under where you order, so you're breathing on them and talking over them as you order. This is the season where everyone is sick, which means a lot of coughing and germs. Gross. 

Cute place and I'm not opposed to paying these types of prices, but I don't like the atmosphere and I don't like paying a lot for coffee and being treated as though my business is insignificant or unimportant. As someone who works in customer service, it really is not that hard to be nice even if you don't feel like it.
author: Severin W.

description: The C U T E S T little coffee shop with an extended back room. I ordered the butterscotch latte and asked the barista to add less sweetener, as I'm not biggest fan of overly sweet things and it was perfect. I also ordered one of their bottled probiotic drinks. Kind of expensive ($7.50) but nonetheless, tasty. Good spot for those of you who enjoy taking/posting pics.
author: Jeri M.

description:
One of my new favorite coffee joints. Right across the street from the local vets office where I went and I'm so glad it's right across the street.

It seemed small, and it IS small but they have so much stuff inside. I wasn't expecting there to be that many things to check out.

They sell everything from candles to soap and other little knick knacks.
I ordered a latte and it was right on point. They brew with Ritual beans which is even better!

I love their decor. Even the packaging for the novelty items that they sell.
They also sell baked goods which I definitely want to try when I go back.

A couple tables but other than that... It's all about the coffee!
author: Jenny Y.

description: There is a warm and cozy allure to hollow; old jazz playing behind the sounds of the streaming milk and friendly staff, what's not to like? This place is most certainly a new favorite in the inner sunset area.
author: Ashlie A.

description: Such a fan of this place. My drinks are always consistent in quality and taste and the pastries are a-mazing (get the cinnamon biscuit). Plus they use Ritual Coffee.
author: Crystal F.

description: Saw this place on a walk with my boyfriend so we stopped in. It is super small, but the coffee is delicious. I had a vanilla latte and to my surprise there was real vanilla bean in the drink. My boyfriend (who is very particular about coffee) got an americano and took one sip and said, "this is fu$#ing good." Great place to stop while walking on Irving. Their treats looked delicious as well.
author: Heather W.

description:
Yes, this place looks amazing. And it has potential to be amazing. And it's probably mostly amazing (given the reviews). But, my experience today was very off-putting. Two reasons, both very important ones:

1) The coffee (French press) was brewed against a timer, and--again--judging by the ambiance and hype around this place, it should have been delicious. However, my cup tasted old and lifeless. So, no matter how fancy and coffee-aficionado-friendly this place looks, they can't win me over with stale beans. 

2) Most importantly, the barista was a surly, miserable jerk. Tall guy with a fresh face and dark hair. He was: unfriendly (from the beginning), unwilling to be (to act, to pretend to be) helpful. I ordered a large French press to share and he put it in one cup even though I said it was for two people. My friend came back to him after he served the cup and ordered a second, which he never made. When I returned to ask about the second cup he angrily informed me that there's a line and that my friend didn't pay anyway. So he never told my friend that-- he just ignored the request. We weren't cutting in line or trying to-- each of us just wanted some coffee (and we were the only customers when we ordered it).

So, two stars, because the barista's attitude was completely uncalled for. And bad coffee, to boot.
author: David C.

description:
Cute little spot.  I like the gifts and trinkets.  The issue is that I was not super impressed with my hot chocolate, and I love hot chocolate.  It was extremely bland.  I went back on a different day and got a yummy latte.  

The itty bitty little caramel cookie really compliments their latte.  The staff is really nice too.  This type of cafe is so badly needed in the Sunset, so I'm thankful for the cuteness and charm.  

While I would try them again for another latte or maybe a mocha, I will still make the trek over to the TenderNob for my hot chocolate fix at my very favorite cafe.
author: Kandi K.

description:
A charming small spot that makes a competitive cappuccino and heats up these waffles that are to die for. There are a few seats inside, where they also sell nice perfumes and trinkets, and sometimes a few seats outside, though the sunset rarely  shares any of the sun overhead, so bring your coat if you plan on getting fresh air. 

Great find for the sunset. A+ on the cap foam and adorable ambiance.
author: Martina R.

description: The place didn't seem busy, but there was a 10+ minute wait for my latte. My latte was a fine. Their cinnamon roll biscuits looked amazing, but I didn't try one.
author: Amin S.

description:
If not for Yelp, I would've driven past this store without even knowing that it was there.  But as part of our Saturday morning long run ritual, my friend and I would first pick a route (all over SF) and then seek out a coffee place to fuel up beforehand.  

This time the route was the north end of Sunset Blvd, going south to Lake Merced, doing a loop there and crossing over to Great Hwy before running along Lincoln and back to our car.  So a coffee place that opens early on a Saturday around Inner / Outer Sunset would be perfect, and Hollow was the first thing that popped up when  I did a Yelp search, so Hollow it is! 

Coffee (Ritual beans) was nice, strong and smooth - Though I'm partial toward Blue Bottle's Three Africans, I'm always open to good coffee and Ritual is definitely high on my list.  

There was a nice selection of pastry too - we shared a croissant, took final gulp on our coffee, and soon were on our way, only after noticing the cute little things up on display and for sale.  I'll be back for a more complete browse very soon!
author: Ange L.

description:
This place is super cute and super charming.  They play slow, folky music like Bon Iver and it's definitely a great place to relax, ease your mind and let your troubles ebb away, if only for a little while.

  The coffee is very strong and heart warming and the desserts are just simply amazing.  The cakes are some of the best I ever had and the next time I go there I have to ask who made them and can we ever get married someday . . . . 

  Besides that, come here to escape from the hustle of the modern world  while you contemplate and exercise your pensive side

  A San Francisco staple for travelers and natives to experience and enjoy.
author: Anthony N.

description:
I am so glad and sad at the same time that I ran across this place in SF. If only I lived here! 

It's the smallest coffee shop I've ever been in with unique trinkets & delicious looking desserts (like the Belgian waffle snack!)

I got the latte ($4 for the large size) & it's the best latte I've ever had, without exaggeration: creamy, thick & full of flavor. Starbucks needs to go out of business...

I wouldn't plan on bringing a laptop or doing any kind of work because the shop only has like 2 tables. It's the kind of place you want to sit & chat with a friend then go about your business for a few minutes.

If I lived in SF, I would be going here every week!
author: Anna N.

description: Nestled in the Sunset, this unobtrusive cafe and gift shop makes you feel like you've stumbled upon a hidden gem. The ambiance is subdued and decor charming. Unique modern rustic home gifts are displayed thoughtfully. My latte was just right and cupcake delicious.
author: Cat N.

description:
This place is TINY. Drove by twice before we found it. Look for the green exterior towards the middle of the block. and NOTE: don't be fooled by that adorable yelp picture, there isn't always a bicycle in the front to catch your eye. lol.

Sooo coffee: It's been a while since I've had a chai latte that actually tasted spicy! It was good but not to die for. My friends had a regular latte and a butterscotch latte. The barista said the butterscotch would be SUPER sweet. He hasn't met my taste buds. It was just the only drink of the three that had any sugar in it.

The ambiance around is quaint and super hipster. Assortment of random, unnecessary and overpriced things abound- but I guess that's just the hipster vibe. 

Also, in general, bathrooms are very important to me. This place had the smallest hallways to get there. So small, I'm not sure if they can truthfully say they are wheelchair accessible. And once you got there, the door seemed to be broken so that you couldn't lock it... problem.

The only thing shocking about this place was a $7 mocha. Which I really wanted. But it was $7. Where do these hipsters work? 

3 stars for a decent half an hour spent on okay-good coffee.
author: Hilary F.

description:
I felt like I was in my dream that I was lost in a small French village.  I loved all the details. (It must be perfect if they had hardwood floor)

I was too excited to enjoy the little things they had, and I don't remember if they had a table to sit outside. I only remember that they had one table for two or three people and one small bench inside. (It's not the cafe where you go to study or play with your laptop, etc.) 

No much choice of baked goods, but I had no complain. There was no table to enjoy sweets and coffee on the table anyway. 

And my cortado was beautifully made, and was wonderful!
author: Micky T.

description: My girls and I just love this place!  Soy latte for me and hot chocolate for the kids.  Delish!   This place is so cute and charming, right out of a woodland fairytale!  I love perusing through their many unique little knick knacks too.  Haven't tried their pastries but they look quite delicious.  Wish there was more seating as sometimes it gets a bit crowded in there.  I do love that it's across from my favorite fabric store, Peapod!
author: Sharon D.

description:
I stopped by Hollow on my way home one day and thought it looked like a nice coffee shop.  It's a little one floor building and decor is a little reminiscent of 19th century.  There are lots of awesome little knick knacks you can buy, (brass spoons, soaps, chocolates, teas, etc.)  you have to see for yourself.  

The staff was really nice and the clientele even nicer.  Everyone was friendly and didn't mind chatting with a newbie in the neighborhood.  I stayed long enough that I got to chat with the owner, William.  It was great hearing his and his wife's story of starting the business. 

One note is that there is no internet and the chairs are set up more for socializing than working or studying (there are only two tables and six chairs inside.)  Be prepared to go the old way of coffee shop; either have internet less computer work, a good book, or good stories to chat with the neighbors.
author: Mel L.

description: This tiny little place awesome! But how to describe? It's like a wooden shack from the old west, but as if you were in France, with fancy cool artisan crafted gifts. Oh, and they have espresso drinks too.
author: Ken L.

description: Such a cute little shop! The wan working is so friendly and sweet! My fiancé and I got a soy chai latte which was killer. The chai is nice and strong! I love it! My fiancé got a soy latte he says it was smooth and creamy. We also got 2 empanadas. One was a beef empanada and the other was much room Gorgonzola both very delicious. We got a cashew scone as well absolutely delicious. I would say it's a bit pricey. Empanadas were $5 each which to me was just a bit overpriced because of the size. Overall a cute little coffee shop. Very cozy!
author: Stephanie B.
