description: If I could give this place 100 stars I would!!!!! This is the best little jewel in the SF! The guy that works here..the owner! Is amazing! He makes you feel like your a friend just having some tea at his house. This shop is every women's dream. Beautiful decor for the home, that have that one of kind look to it. And handmade feel to every little bottle opener, and everything in between. Just in love with this cafe shop! My friend and I didn't want to leave. Will be back for life! Thank you for putting your heart into this shop to the owner, you two have really made a amazing place that needs to come to Los Gatos! Xoxo
author: Holly L.

description:
An unexpected, hidden delight, it's a tiny shop crammed with an eclectic selection of soaps, incense, greeting cards, antlers (many antlers), tea strainers, candles, shea butter, planters, etc.  The retail items show an appreciation for nature and a vintage, worn in look. I love the small animal figurines and couldn't resist getting a squirrel nutcracker.  From the outside it looks like a tiny retail shop - but they also make incredible espresso drinks.

The amazing lattes and other espresso drinks are made with Ritual Roasters beans.  There's something special about the foam.  The nonfat latte is rich, smooth, deep in flavor and almost creamy. However, it only comes in one size ($2.85), and it's TINY.  It's the smallest latte I've ever had.  I guess the size matches the size of the shop. Much as I loved the latte, it's so small that I can't possibly get through the morning with just one of those.

I spotted cookies (e.g., cashew, chocolate chip) and handmade truffles (made by a friend of the owner).  I tried a Meyer lemon shortbread, a delicate cookie with a hard glaze.  I noticed a tiny bit of lemon rind but the cookie didn't have much lemon flavor.  The Madras curry truffle was creamy with a soft, milk chocolate ganache center but it didn't have curry flavor.  I liked the Meyer lemon truffle better.  It had a thin shell and a soft, creamy white chocolate ganache center.  You can taste the lemon but the flavor isn't overpowering.  
 
There are two tiny tables inside for coffee drinkers.
author: Lolia S.

description:
* Coffee: Espresso drinks only. No drip or press offerings. Made with Ritual beans. Yea!
* Location: Very small. Only three indoor tables, but it makes for a cozy setting with interesting decor.
* Service: Quick and friendly.
* Food: I had a Guinness cupcake that was pretty tasty.
VERDICT: I'd go back and recommend it to others that are in the area.
author: Dennis V.

description:
Great coffee (better than the rest in the inner sunset), but minus one star for opening so late. Clearly it must cater to the at-home, student, and hipster  local crowd, but 8am on weekdays and 9am on weekends? Really? Isn't that after most have left for their 9-5s and weekend road trips?

Also, I secretly want to believe that some of the "handcrafted" trinkets were made by the hipster baristas upstairs, but alas, I don't think that's true.
author: Todd H.

description: Stopped in here for a hot chocolate and peanut butter cookie. The woman working was lovely and I thoroughly enjoyed my snack. Charming interior. Great place to read a book as I did or meet up with a friend.
author: Erin S.

description: Adorable looking coffee shop with great tasting coffee. I have been here a few times and have always been really happy with the friendly service. Will definitely be back.
author: Julia T.

description:
It wasn't the coffee that lured me in (as maybe 3 of you know, I am a certified tea drinker). It was actually the amazing hints of green, metal, and wire as I peeked into the window that gave me glitter berry eyes and I knew that I was in lovelooveloooooove. The owner, William, was amazingly patient with my mom and me as we cooed and bustled around his precious lil coffee shop. I really want the pewter fish measuring spoons ($62) and my birthday is on December 14th. Okay, thanks. 

We dropped $80 on merch (okay, the stuff is kinda pricey, but I'm willing to pay for things I really like) but unfortunately did not try any of the goods... I'm thinking that I'm going to stop by some other day and try out those gorgeous treats under glass domes and maybe a cappuccino (a dude who came in and ordered a latte said that he hasn't had coffee this good since he was in Europe. Considering the last great cup of coffee I had was in Austria, this means everything). 

P.S. Check out their wooden doors in tha back of the store. Wood taken from a fence in Santa Cruz. How cool is that?
P.P.S. His wife is a fantabulous interior decorator which explains why I loveloooveloooooove Hollow.
author: Natasha P.

description: Cute, very small cafe with wonderful coffee! Small minus for very limited seating area, but the coffee is so good I'll get over it! Worth a detour.
author: Rebecka H.

description:
I love this place... I wish it was in Boston!

Most importantly, the coffee is unbelievably delicious. Like.. really good, probably some of the best I've ever had. I've also tried the Guinness cupcake and it was moist and light. Loved it. 

The atmosphere of the shop is fantastic. It's so little and quirky. There's a lot of knick knacks you can purchase. Makes waiting around enjoyable.

All in all, I will come back every time I'm in town. I LOVE this place!
author: Saba N.

description: Cute charming little place but it only has two tables and a couple of benches. The cafe offers a nice arrange of pastries and has a variety of items for sale, such as $10 chocolate bars, metal straws and such. I had a small butterscotch latte which was nice and sweet. Nice little gem in the neighborhood.
author: Xteethx B.

description: I had the vanilla bean latte one afternoon- and would continue to do so every day until the end of time (If I could will myself to walk over every day). I always have to ask for less syrup or sweetener at every coffee shop I go to, but not here. My drink was silky  smooth with just a touch of sweet vanilla goodness. I'm excited to come back and try the butterscotch latte next!
author: Mahkayla A.

description: AMAZING! Cutest little spot to study and sip on a coffee. Really nice atmosphere too :)
author: Page F.

description:
This place fucking ROCKS!!!!!

I was walking around the neighborhood looking for a good small coffee place to have some good morning joe, I just happen to stumble upon this place.

At first I thought it wasn't going to as great as some other small places I had tried, but after having some of their stuff I was blown out of this WORLD!!!!!

I would definitely come back here again for coffee and other stuff no one cares about. But until I have some more money, I would recommend this place to many of my buddies looking for a good coffee place to hang out in the Inner Sunset area if they so do happen to be around there. 

=)
author: Jacen W.

description:
I just went here yesterday for the first time. It is so incredibly cute. Very small but absolutely lovely. Lots of great little gifts are for sale like candles, soaps, and lotions. All handmade and local too, it appears. The coffee bar is near the back while all the products are in front as you walk in. 

Coffee was delicious, strong, and perfect. Staff was friendly. They had some really intriguing sounding pastry items (including a Guinness cupcake) but I did not venture to try since the coffee was already a bit of a splurge for me. True, the coffee and all the goods for sale are pretty pricey, but I would go here purely for the experience. I sat with my book and sipped my mocha, listening to the soothing running water from the wall mounted fountain. The barista was playing the first Fleet Foxes album and I thought maybe I was in heaven.

I can't really believe I just said that, but, there you go.

Good to cuddle up with a book and have a nice cup of coffee and maybe a treat!
author: India K.

description:
Hollow serves the best espresso drinks in the neighborhood, and though the coffee size is singular and small, taste is exceptional.

Come and linger at one of their two ever-so-romantic marble-topped tables, pause and peruse a great variety of their gift items (coasters, soaps, pocket mirrors, decorative handles and hooks, unusual and tasteful knick-knacks).  

The space is small, but sweet.
author: Claudine C.

description:
hollow is a hidden treasure on irving...

it's so easy to pass and yet the aroma of fresh brewing coffee will take you back.
what won me over was the AMAZING decor of the shop.

i'm an interior design geek and i immediately fell in love with everything about hollow...
so warm and inviting.
my new favorite coffeeshop in all of san francisco, hands down.

got a chai latte and it was beyond perfection.
the perfect balance of creamy and spicy.

i'll definitely be back, little gem.
this time i'll be sure to pick up some tokyomilk products and a sweet treat or two.
author: Kirstie A.

description: Ritual Coffee, great small snacks, and a gorgeous little hide-away space filled with glittery gifts. They have French press coffee and an espresso machine. They know what they're doing with coffee here. And the cookies and empanadas are lovely. Don't come here if you're high-maintenance looking for a credit-card accepting + meal + laptop station. It's a spot for a thirty minute visit with a friend in the mid-Sunset. And I love it for that.
author: Catherine C.

description: I stopped in for coffee after yoga class about a week ago.  My americano was perfect.  This is a very tiny coffee shop, cute, but only 4 chairs inside.  They have a limited menu (no fat-free milk, etc...).  I probably won't be back since it isn't close to my home or work.
author: Christy L.

description:
The Product: They use Ritual Expresso, which tastes pretty good. What's better is that it's CHEAP - $2 for a DOUBLE shot of expresso! Not even Starbucks can beat that price.

The Venue: Cute. Yup, I said it. Definitely cute. Not good for studying or for personal conversations, though. Because it's a small garage of a place, any conversation will be heard by all patrons, and forget about trying to study on those cold, wobbly metal tables. I'd say get your cheap shot of caffeine, enjoy it, and get out.

Overall: I'm not sure I'd categorize the place as a "cafe." They dont have coffee (an Americano is not a coffee - it is an expresso with hot water), and though they have expresso-based drinks, snacks, and seating, it's tough to label it a "cafe." Semantics aside, cheap expressos can't be beat.
author: Gun-Ik P.

description:
Small, intimately decorated cafe, deeply brewed, tasty Ritual coffee and Guinness cupcakes. +++

Also enjoyed the empanadas. I wish I loved closer so I could claim this as my local secret coffee spot.
author: Michele A.

description:
I have been waiting on Yelping this place, since I didn't want my favorite little secret to get out... oh well. Great things are meant to be shared. I guess. This  place is amazing. For some reason it really reminds me of "Lord of the Rings" which I LOVE. I imagine hobbits would hang out in a place like this. If they had a coffee addiction. It's just so... cute and charming. Kind of how I like to imagine myself on a good day. 

Their latte and cappuccino are to die for. I drink mine with nonfat milk, and don't notice any difference in the foam consistency, which I sometimes find at other places when I get it made with nonfat. As for sweet treats, I've tried their chewy salted caramel cookie and the oatmeal cake, both of which were divine. This is the perfect place to sit and savor a delicious cup of coffee and a bite to eat on a foggy morning, which in the Sunset district, is basically everyday. 

Sigh.
author: Jillian M.

description:
Hollow is an adorable, rustic, micro coffee shop- similar to something you might see in Kyoto only it's in the Sunset! I go here fairly often, but despite their friendly facade, I hate to say, I've never really gotten the best service. There used to be a time where being a pretentious barista was expected, and perhaps even a bit charming, but shops haven't been like that in years. I can't remember the last time i felt attitude at FourBarrel or Sightglass or Stumptown or Handsome or Intelligentsia or really any other 3rd wave shop. So why you guys? Lose the 'tude dudes and get with the times...or at least do a better job keeping the grounds out of your cold brew.
That said, I'm still throwing you 4-stars because I think Hollow is awesome. I love the space, I love the aesthetic, and being a Sunset resident, I'm a big supporter of new *cool* businesses around the hood. 
Just please leave the mopey elitism at home and try to be as friendly as your shop's aesthetic would lead people to believe...and maybe dial it down on the random products everywhere.
author: Greg S.

description:
Did I ever tell you how much I LOVE SF??? This is the only city that I have been to besides NY where there are so many cute lil restaurants and coffee shops, none of those boring franchises.

This place is suuuuuuper CUTE! 

I always passed by it walking back home and I never noticed it until I saw it on yelp. I stopped by today to look inside and try their coffee, and I totally fell in looooooooooooove.

I got the machiatto and I must say that I never knew that machiatto means an expensive teen, tiny expresso with a shot of foamed milk. Nevertheless, I really liked my experience here.

Decor - CHECK: antique-style, wood all around...LOVE IT.
Place to chill - CHECK: There are 2 tables and 1 outside.
Taste of the coffee - CHECK: the machiatto, although small, was yummy but I had to add sugar.
Eats - CHECK: there were super yummy looking sweets...nothing else, didn't see any bagels which I love, no soups or sandwiches but that's okay b/c the sweets looked heavenly.
Choices - CHECK: They didn't have like 1000 types of coffee, just a few selections like machiatto, latte, americano, mocha etc  which I actually liked b/c I was able to scan once and know what I wanted. EASY.

In my opinion, this is a lovely lil coffee shop, a perfect place to meet up with a friend (don't know if meeting up with more friends is possible b/c it's super small) and drink yummy coffee with yummy baked goods. Can't wait to go back and try their other coffees and yum yum goods!
author: Judy Y.

description: I stumbled upon this place a couple of years ago while walking my puppy. I live 3 blocks away and absolutely LOVE this place! Great homemade pastries/sweets, artisan coffee. Small sitting area, but comfortable.
author: Pratima M.

description: Hollow is our official coffee destination when we're in the neighborhood. Expertly prepared coffee, uber cozy shop, tasty nibbles, and a super friendly counter man made for a pleasant drizzly Saturday for us.
author: Norman G.

description: So many cool things sold in addition to delicious and carefully crafted coffee at Hollow. Huge vanilla bean marshmallow in my coffee/coco concoction will set any day right!
author: Busy P.

description: Love this place! It's the only non-chain near where I live, where the coffee is super duper awesome. The snack selection is also yummy, and the whole place has an easy-going vintage feel. It could be a little bigger, but it might lose it's charm. Even worth a visit if you're not in the area. Cute selection of interesting etsy-type gift items.
author: Liz R.

description:
I really appreciate they way the owners have chosen to stay small and specialize. The espresso drinks are superbly executed, the baked goods are excellent, and the staff, at least today, was friendly and helpful. I don't need a wall-size menu of food and drink options when the limited selection is all excellent.

In addition to being a cafe, there is a curio shop aspect, wherein they sell antique glasswear, unique service pieces, and other kitchy items for the home and table, which are reasonably priced and a very well curated selection.

My only concern is that one day soon I will arrive and not be able to sit because there are only two tables, but any more would crowd the space. 

This place is great, so please only go for take-out, so that I will always be able to find a seat.
author: Quinn S.

description: Finally, people who like to make coffee, in the sunset. I wish I lived closer to them. Thank you, Hollow, for making me a delicious mocha and not a hot chocolate. My GF swooned over the alfahores and the random items for sale are ridiculously cool. FINALLY!!!
author: Bam A.

description: Great coffee. Yupster atmosphere. Super lame that they don't have wifi.
author: John M.

description: The French press Ritual was unforgettable! I didn't pay attention to the name of the blend, but it had that fruity, blueberry aftertaste. Almost like Bella Donovan by Blue bottle, but  with thicker texture. The only negative thing is their straws. They had those cute paper straws that melt when you put them in a cup with hot coffee, and it tastes like wet paper. Please, get some regular straws guys!:)
author: Katie K.

description: Such a nice coffee shop, loved the matcha latte. Not too sweet just perfect. There is also a nice store next door.
author: Anna K.

description:
i stumbled across hollow trekking my way to work. hollow's a hidden coffee shop with serious coffee, scrumptious treats (hello Guinness cupcakes) and cute trinkets for gifting.

the baristas here know their espresso drinks. granted their smallest coffee is $3 but that little cup packs a caffeinated punch.
author: Lola L.

description:
Oh so very convenient! Not only was I able to stray away from going to Starbucks and come to Hollow instead, but I was also able to enjoy a cup of mocha while doing my laundry at the end of the block! 

This place is seriously really really REALLY small. Just having 2-3 customers in line makes the place cramped already. There was only one person working today so I was in line for a bit but I didn't mind because I was able to entertain myself with all their antique looking sale items. So when you come in here it feels like you are going into the hollow of a tree (duh, Eugenia, that's why they're called Hollow!) because it's dark with minimal lighting. I personally think that's pretty cool. 

I ordered a small mocha. I guess I failed to see that for a single shot it was $3.25, double shot $3.50 and a large $4.00. All their other coffee/lattes range about $3-4. While I was waiting for my drink I saw the guinness cupcakes other yelpers yelped about but my eyes were more fixated on (sorry if I butcher the name) the soft chocolate caramel sea salt cookie...... so I had to get one. 

Mocha was good-- definitely kept me up the entire day after only had 3 hours of sleep and will for sure come back for more. The cookie was yes, small and tiny but I loved it. The sweetness with the mix of the salty-- yum! Oh and it was oh so very soft and chewy! 

P.S. There are about three tables inside if you do wish to enjoy your coffee there-- just remember it gets crampy when there's more than 3 customers.
author: Eugenia G.

description: Unique and charming little cafe. Awesome empanadas, great coffee and friendly baristas.
author: Aquamarine M.

description: Unique.  Ambiance, decor, coffee, and pastries are the reasons to check this place out. It's not a run in and run out place for your morning coffee. It's a sit down, relax, and enjoy your coffee kind of place. Along those lines, service is not for those in a rush. Very euro.
author: Hubert C.

description: These guys are among the growing few who know how to get coffee right--very fresh, medium roast, microfoamed milk, not too hot.  The cappuccino was just right.  There is an eclectic collection of soaps and sundries, along with a short, but fresh and homemade menu of baked goods.  I tried the sausage empanada which was good if not great.  The sweet offerings looked to be 5 star.
author: Joseph J.

description: Best vanilla latte I've ever had. The staff is friendly and the atmosphere is unbeatable if you're looking for a quaint study sesh or meeting space.
author: Rose C.

description: I really love the vibe of this little cafe. I ordered a latte and was not disappointed with the flavor of coffee! Not too strong, but not too sweet. It was very delicious and the servers there were extremely friendly. They have a nice little back room you can go into if you want to talk, or you can sit in the front and read quietly. The drink was about as much as they would charge you at starbucks, but had a more natural taste to it. I will definitley be coming back!
author: Leann C.

description: Love this place. The gifts are adorable. The pastries are fantastic. And the coffee is delicious. And best of all, the staff was friendly.
author: Jillian M.

description: When I need coffee and  a little break from work I come here. It's such a tiny space with a homey feel that is tranquil and very relaxing. All of the baked goods look tempting but I've yet to try them since I stay away from processed sugars as much as possible.
author: Ericka A.

description:
I live in Phoenix, where cool stuff exists but is hard to come by.  When I visited San Francisco on a band tour, we stayed at a friend's apartment in Sunset, I got up early to stroll around by myself and see what kind of neat stuff I could find, and perhaps procure a hot beverage to enjoy as I walked.

I untimately decided on this little spot to get a cup of tea.  It's tiny and narrow, and the atmosphere is kind of...magical, in a way.  It seems like the kind of place you would find burrowed into a hill in Narnia, run by a talking hedgehog.

There was actually a tea list with detailed descriptions of the teas.  No store-bought teabags here, mate.  I chose one and spent the rest of the morning nursing a piping hot paper cup of it.

I would need to visit Hollow more times to decide whether it deserves five stars.  But it struck me as the sort of place that would disappear as soon as you turned your back, as if it had never existed at all, and you wondered if it was just a dream that you can't forget.
author: Diana W.

description:
4.5 stars for coffee and bake goods
2.5 stars for service
Overall 3.5 stars

Stopped by this Sat. at 11:00am to get coffee before a photo shoot! I tried their guiness beer chocolate cupcake, which was AMAZING!! Their coffee was also yummy!  We tried the latte, soy latte and mocha, which were all made exceptionally well.  Their prices were a bit steep for their small portions but we're paying for the quality.

The service can be inconsistent.  During my first visit, I was greeted by a friendly and approachable barista who explained their business with a super smile! =) However, our most recent visit was different. There was no one tending the counter when we walked in. When we did get service, our enthusiasm in trying their menu was met more by annoyance and inconvenience.

When my friend asked a simple question, "what kind of tea do you have?" the woman responded with no expression "everything but earl grey." Dude, who answers like that? EVERYTHING? Does this place really have EVERYTHING? Do they have Oolong tea or Pu-erh tea?

I was really excited to try their beverages on my return visit but only to encounter such awful customer service!  =P
author: Leeseuh K.

description: One of the best lattes I've ever had!  They open a bit later in the morning, so it's not great if you are looking for something early, but if you are like me and like to get a run or some errands in before your morning cup, it's perfect.  The space is pretty small, but there's a fun charm to that.  I love stopping in here on the weekends :)
author: Kirsten M.

description: So, I've been debating whether to put this posting up as I kind of like the fact that this place still a little bit unknown. I've been coming here regularly for three years now. It's kind of become somewhat of a second home to me. I know everyone who works here and have become friends with each of them. It's nice to come down to shoot the sh*t with Alex, Dakota, or the owners, Dawn and Will, when I get tired of being pent-up in my work-from-home life. If I could be so bold, Hollow is my Cheers. I used to drink the coffee, which is amazing. But since then I've been forced to lower my caffeine levels and get a chai latte - it's nice and spicy, just the way I like it. Plus they have almond milk, hurrah! The music is always something I would have in my own player, and all in all, it's a perfect combination of elements to make me feel right at home.
author: Carmen C.

description: Awful service, the barista seemed thouroughly disinterested and annoyed he had to deal with us, but they know how to make a good cup of coffee and use excellent beans.
author: Joe S.

description: Yelp is so funny. I have been going to this cafe ever since I moved into the hood. This is the least pretentious coffee shop in SF with not only awesome coffee (with rates comparable to every other coffee shop in town), the folks who own and work at this joint are solid. I dig the fact I spend my money locally with these hard working shop owners. Oh, and,  everyone needs to try the vanilla latte. Insane.
author: Paige M.

description: So glad we happened across this excellent spot for great coffee and baked goods in Inner Sunset. It was cold and rainy out, and this place defines cozy. If I could have packed this place up and brought it back to Philadelphia with me, I would have.
author: Sam G.

description: This is my favorite coffee shop in SF! It exudes charm like no other--very rustic and full of personality. Major pluses include interesting pastry selection and curiosos (toiletries, antique items, specialty chocolates, all in good taste). Their drinks are good, but I should say they have "potential." Lattes are on the watery side so I would recommend doubling up.
author: Nicole L.

description: Enjoyed this place so much! A cute little nook, and William (the barista) was so great!! Super friendly and made the best lattes! We were visiting from Atlanta, and he made us feel so at home in the city!!  :-)
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I love everything about this place. Superb coffee and delictable desserts. I was super impressed with the Chewy Salted Caramel Cookie! I have to get some for my mom and ship it to her. If you're like us who like the savory with the sweet, you have to try this cookie! 

The vibe here is wonderful. I hate to say this but the first word that comes to mind is DREAMY. If I ever own a coffee shop it would be like Hollow.

An unexpected treat is their merchandise selection. They have so many unique products that you won't be able to find anywhere else. I already have 5 things on my wish list.
author: Cin H.

description: Tucked away- its easy to miss but once  inside its easy to see that this coffee shop has a lot of character. Its cute rustic knicknacks are unique. I especially like the lacquered wooden tape measure. They also had metal reusable straws, ahnd forged scissors and random antiques. The coffee on the other had was sub-par.
author: Naomi K.

description: great soy cappuccino, flaky pain au chocolate.  the atmosphere is relaxing, friendly.  if you live anywhere close by, this should be your regular visit
author: Tony T.

description: Small cozy cafe with interesting items for your home. The main attraction is that they serve Ritual based coffee. And that is a big attraction if you don't like lines, scenesters, or going all the way to the mission.
author: E. W.

description:
A little piece of hipster heaven here in the Sunset. Great service and decor, delicious food (Guiness cupcakes, Banana cupcake, Homemade marshmallows), and awesome coffee. Cool hipster merchandise.

Minus one star for not having wifi, not having a ton of seating and not being open late.
author: Renata B.

description: I live around the corner from the Hollow and have bought coffee, such as lattes and cappuccinos, as well as pastries for several years since it first opened. The coffee and pastries are delicious.  I am reluctantly giving the Hollow a two-star rating because of the painfully slow service the café provides. I understand that the café is a small business and the coffee takes time to prepare, but the employees working the coffee machine and cashier are unreasonably slow in serving customers, almost to the point of unprofessionalism.  Today, I was the first person in line, but I noticed that the cafe was packed with sitting customers. The cashier essentially ignored me standing in front of the cash register while she spoke to someone else for about five minutes. The barista started chatting to a few customers who entered the café after me and also ignored me. The last straw, and what caused me to leave, was that I noticed a lot of empty cups near the coffee machine that indicated outstanding coffee orders that the barista had yet to fill.  I have very little time to wait for my morning coffee, so I decided to just walk the few blocks to Andronico's and get my coffee there. I have spoken to the owners a few times, and I wonder if they would appreciate the lack of service their employees are providing their customers.  At this point, I am reluctant to go back to the Hollow, and, instead, will buy my coffee at the Starbucks or Andronicos, although I would say the Hollow has better coffee. The quality of the coffee simply does not make up for the poor customer service at the Hollow.
author: Faye D.

description: Coffee bores me - it's watery and lacks the depth that only espresso can provide. I like that slightly bitter, caramely  taste that for a great shot of espresso. Hollow is cute and does things right!
author: Jade W.

description: Update-went here a few more times and the baristas turned from robotic sods to humans. I gotta give them props for being more friendly and kind. Love this place.
author: SForiginal T.

description: I admit this place leans a bit on the pricey side BUT don't let that stop you from trying it! I usually order a hot cocoa with a side of their scrumptious pastry (changes all the time). The baristas are pretty friendly and you don't get the douchey attitude you'd expect when you walk in. Drop that coin and give this place a go.
author: Nancy L.

description: What an adorable little coffee shop! I had a great chat with William, who owns the place with his wife, and I even bought a delicious perfume while I was there. They have a great selection of locally made gifts and chocolates and body products... And my latte was perfect. Definitely will be coming back to support this awesome small business!
author: Toby B.

description: They do what they do well.  The barista was friendly and courteous.  I had an Americano and pecan crisp and both were very very good.  If you want coffee, you CAN get it here, but you will have to wait about five minutes so they can make you a fresh French Press, which is always worth the wait.  A great quirky little hidden gem of a SF Cafe.
author: Jon C.

description: Too precious for some tastes, this mini cafe does properly-executed espresso drinks and has an early 20C vibe, complete with Chicago swing music and stamped, round number price tags on classically designed housewares and toiletries.  The Guinness-chocolate cupcake is really good.  Not a laptop place but fine for chatting or reading for a bit.  Extra star for the completeness of the atmosphere.
author: Chris M.

description:
Get the mushroom
Gorgonzola empanada! Coffee was also delicious. They didn't have any whipped cream so I used one of their home made vanilla bean marshmallows instead.
author: Chey B.

description: So charming with the odd little doodads all around! So tiny (just 2 tables) and cute! And Ritual coffee! I'm almost never in this 'hood, and this is one of those serendipitous finds I'm delighted to have stumbled on. I sat at the marble-topped table for half an hour this afternoon, listening to quiet music and the splashing of an indoor fountain, and enjoyed the serenity while I caffeinated. Then I tried one of the Tokyo Milk perfume testers, and now I smell delicious.
author: Fawn F.

description: Nice "TINY" Coffee house. Very cute and delicious drinks.
author: Mario A.

description:
Beautiful peaceful interior and delicious espresso. Like others may have mentioned, this is not a place for drip coffee.

I ordered an Americano, and the flavor was rich; the caffeine was strong. I loved that the barista took great care in making my drink; it was a little longer than other places may take but well worth the wait. If you're coming here, sit inside for a bit and take the time to sip your drink. It feels like time stops inside Hollow... it's so peaceful :)
author: Erin W.

description: Be sure to check out the kitschy kitchen tools, they have some fun stuff!
author: Sarah D.

description:
greg a. is brain damaged

Hollow makes the best latte or americano I've ever had, 10-out-of-10 points over anywhere in Paris I've been. Owners are friendly, and conversations have been intriguing and interesting.

Lots of cool stuff for sale in the shop as well.

Great Inner Sunset neighborhood location, cozy interior, and tables. I couldn't ask for anything more in a  neighborhood "espresso" shop.
author: Enoch K.

description: Cute little cafe. The guy there was very friendly. Nice things for gifts.
author: Colin P.

description:
L A M E

this place has no coffee, just espresso. don't be fooled by the ritual coffee sign, the fact that its categorized under 'coffee & tea' on yelp, or the fact that everyone reviewing this place calls it a 'coffee shop'. IT'S NOT.

yes, that's right: some of us don't like strong bitter thimbles of flavor, we prefer a rich warm soothing CUP of coffee.
author: Greg A.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars if there was more space, and therefore more tables. Otherwise, it's a gem in the sunset. The place is cozy, the music was soothing, and the service was accommodating.

The espresso was amazing! (warning: they do not serve coffee, but they have Ritual espresso beans and the Americano they whip up is just delightful). 

For pastries, they have vega GLUTEN FREE peanut butter chocolate chip cookies. I was in heaven. Thank you so much for making these! I am definitely going to return for those alone.
author: Deirdre P.

description: "Super cute (and tiny) place. Great coffee and my spinach & feta empanada was really good!"
author: Serene V.

description: This place rocks, serving Ritual Coffee, they pull a darn good espresso. Along with Trouble Coffee on Judah down by the beach are the 2 best coffee spots in Inner Sunset/Sunset. The Barista's are friendly and they have allot of cool knick knacks that you will want to buy, but not sure why.
author: dub g.

description:
didn't even know about this place until recently.  

yesterday i got the vegan choc chip/peanut butter cookie.  that was pretty good....you know, for being vegan and all.  haha.

today i got this cinammon sugar biscuit (scone?), which was really, really good.  it also had some chocoalate chips in it.

my friend got an empanada that he said was decent, other than it being slightly cold in the center....

i asked where the baked goods came from, and the chick told me that she didn't know because she doesn't get there early enough to see the truck drop off the stuff.  i didn't want to break it to her that there are "other ways" to find these things out.  

the lattes i got were good also....they use Ritual beans, as is stated in some of these other reviews.

so, i ordered a "medium" latte yesterday....the response i got was a scoff, and a lecture on how there were only two sizes.  it was like i had ordered a grande frap from him or something.  sorry dude...my bad.  i know, i'm so stupid to think that there may be more than two sizes of a coffee beverage.  of course, i didn't mention to him that it was slightly confusing, as there are three prices next to the word "latte" on the board.  i didn't take offense though, as i'm assuming that he's just pissed that he has to spend time in the Sunset instead of the Mission or something....
author: Miss P.

description:
Hollow is a great little coffee shop run by very friendly people. It's got a cool, unusual vibe, too. Not to geek out, but if Frodo Baggins drank espresso, he'd go here. 

Ok, lord, that was really geeky. I'm not sure I can recover from that. 

Anyway, Hollow provides a much-needed source for good coffee in the Inner Sunset. They serve Ritual beans and have been trained in the caffeinated arts by those same commie-inspired coffee ninjas. Which means when you get your, say, Americano, it tastes like it should. 

The place is a little small and the prices are a little high. Also, the hours are a bit limited for dayjob-having people like me. Otherwise, this would be a five-star no-brainer. 

But those minor points aside, Hollow is a fantastic, welcome addition to the Inner Sunset. 

More than that, the owners seem genuine, humble, and down to earth -- the type of people you like to see succeed. 

So help 'em out and swing by.
author: Bryan H.

description: Excellent cappuccinos in a great atmosphere.  My new favorite cafe!
author: Alexandra T.

description: Omg best coffee ever.  Come in and let Alex guide you to a higher level of charm.
author: Melba T.

description:
Five stars for their rockin' moist Guiness Choco cupakes!

Thanks L for the recommendation!
author: Steph Y.

description:
This place is the epitome of San Francisco hipster. It is a small, hole-in-the-wall type of coffee shop that also sells organic soaps, candles, and other useless trinkets. When I first walked by on the street, I wasn't even sure this was a cafe. Nearly every inch of counter space was covered with superfluous wares for sale, when all I really wanted was a cup of coffee. The poor barista barely had any room to work and only had about a 5 by 5 inch square of counter on which he could serve my drink. From the customer side, the general layout of this already small space was confusing, because there is no clear area for ordering and paying. I understand that Hollow is trying to be unique and hip and cool, but I don't think the overdone decor was worth the compromise in functionality. I think to be a true fan of Hollow, you really have to buy into this contrived image of the "alternative" cafe. 

Now on to the actual coffee, I ordered the Titanic II, which is essentially a dark chocolate mocha with a giant handmade marshmallow floating in the center. This drink was served in a bowl - no handle. I guess I was suppose to drink it Asian-style, which is fine, because I'm Asian (duh) and drink stuff out of bowls all the time. I just didn't expect it coming from a bona fide cafe.  And to be honest, it felt a little weird sitting outside holding a bowl up to my face. Overall, I was satisfied with the quality. The dark chocolate in the mocha was delicious and it was not too sweet, with a nice balance of coffee and chocolate. A pet peeve of mine though is that the drink was lukewarm, whereas I like my coffee to be piping hot. 

The takeaway: Good coffee at reasonable prices, especially for a cafe in the city. This is why I give Hollow 4 stars. However, I could do away with all the extraneous decoration. It did not make me feel cool. It just made me feel like a phony hipster.
author: Lina Z.

description: Yeah, I agree this is a neet little place.... VERY little actually... and a lot of the trinketty stuff inside is pretty cool and not "cheap Chinese crap" by any means... the woman who was working the day I was there was super friendly and very chill... but Im sorry, $3.95 for a mocha in a cup the size of an espresso shot??? Times are tough but COME ON. I was having such a great conversation with the woman about Robert Jordan's "Wheel of Time" fantasy series that when she told me the price, I didn't feel right bitching about it. At the time it was ok... nice atmosphere and all, but afterwards I was like... "did I actually pay $3.95 for a few sips of a mocha?". That's ridiculous. I haven't been back since.
author: Daniel W.

description:
Ritual coffee in the inner sunset - YES!  This place was once a hole-in-the-wall hair dresser's.  The owners turned it into a very cozy coffee nook and serves great coffee.  I had a decaf for only 2 bucks and it rocked my world to sit and sip it there.  

I hope this place stays in the neighborhood for a long time.  

Oh- as an update to a previous poster's suggestion - they did add a 2 seater cushioned bench on the outside so you can sit there.
author: Linh T.

description:
I just wish I can own this cafe~ and tell all my friends, I did all the work! 
All the pretty selling items on the wall are like sophisticated decor, and I can stand there forever, and awwwww and ohhhhh all the goods. 
Coffees are great, but I really didn't wanna see the brand of chocolate, which wasn't as special as all the other things in this cafe... besides it was hot chocolate mix... But all baked goods are gourmet recipes, and the place always has a nice stem of flower on each table.
author: Yuri K.

description: I LOVE this place.  Come here if only for an impeccable cup of espresso. It is the right quantity, temperature, and flavor served in an appropriately sized itty-bitty mug.  The tasty sweets and yuppie trinkets are just a perk.  Marshmallows! Did I mention marshmallows?! This tiny nook is comfy and quaint - a real gem.
author: Carol W.

description:
I  prayed & prayed to the coffee gods for a cafe like Hollow to be delivered to my neighborhood, and voila! It appears the coffee gods love me. 

Hollow is an absolute Sunset neighborhood gem, tucked into a tiny, unassuming green storefront beside the cigar shop (a gem in its own right). It's a cozy place to sit and read a book while sipping an authentic  espresso drink made with Ritual coffee--some of the best in SF--or to just grab an on-the-fly cup on your walk to the farmers' market. But what makes this cafe truly special is not even just the fact that the coffee is great--it's the uncommon vibe, the delicious pastries, and the friendly, interesting owners. It's the sense of discovery when you walk in, the feeling that it was plucked right out of the Mission and dropped into the Sunset. Think Mission cafe meets Polk street shopping at World Market prices. It's nigh unto impossible for me to leave Hollow without adding some gorgeous candle or funky objet d'art to my espresso order. 

Would it cheesy to say you had me at hollow?
author: Lavinia S.

description: This place is freakin' tiny, but it works perfectly with its cuteness and style.  I had the double-shot mocha, and it was smooth, strong, and delicious.  The one barista working there was super nice.  Their pastries were definitely unique, and had interesting little trinkets (lotions and utensils) on the side for sale.
author: Tiffany K.

description: This eclectic, magical spot served me a very fine espresso drink and fascinated me with the beautiful matchboxes, candles, purse mirrors, deer antlers, metal pots, and all sorts of unusual things. It is tiny and the style is nothing I would think to choose for myself, but I felt like I was in some kind of enchanted garden shed and that Narnia might be very nearby.  I like it.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Wow, they make a very good Americano here. 

But there are some negatives to Hollow that must be discussed: 

1) Only one size offering, and it is very tiny size. 

2) The prices are higher than average 

3) They are slow! It's great they take such care with each order, but if you are in a hurry and more than 1 person is ahead of you, then forget it. 

4) Too dark and narrow. Not sure why they try to sell the oddities throughout this tiny place, but it seems to me it would be better to make the space 100% cafe and give more room to customers. 

5) No drip coffee, just americano. Which is fine, but as I stated above, it's slow service. 

But I still go back when I have time, because the Americano is fantastic.
author: Sir Paul L.

description: I've been to this place twice and had horrible service both times. Both times the baristas have ignored me and the second time they forgot to make half my order. Instead of an apology they acted annoyed that they had to make another drink for me.  The coffee is decent but not worth it for the terrible service! There are plenty of better coffee shops in the neighborhood with great service.
author: Paige B.

description:
Great espresso drinks.  Hollow has espresso down.  Everything from steaming the milk to pulling the shots is done well.  Macchiato served in a demitasse and cappuccino served in cappuccino cup!

Best of all, $2.50 for an awesome macchiato.  

The interior is tiny.  Three or four inside is a crowd.  The drinks menu is on the left as you walk and if you don't know it's there, you'll surely miss it.  

In the past, Hollow only did espresso, but they have coffee also now.  Coffee is ground and made to order in a French press so it does take a few minutes to prepare.
author: James Y.

description:
After Canvas closed, our neighborhood is so desperate for a decent cafe it's willing to take anything, and Hollow is a very very pleasant surprise.  First of, I never thought Ritual Coffee and its tightly controlled venture would ever grace us, the part of the city that is not synonymous with HIP, with their coffee.  Frankly I have no idea why or how Ritual has superior coffee, but the lattes I have had are pretty darn tasty.  And they are pretty darn small, so they MUST be good. 

If you still can't smell the desperation, I will tell you that I am willing to bump the stars to 5, despite the fact that I think the place is unfortunately too small and there is too much going on (great color scheme, but I feel like I am stuck in a Mendocino gift shop).  I mean, is this like the only place where if you see ONE person ahead of you, you are thinking, oh I am screwed, there won't be enough room for a whole other human being in the cafe. 

When are we gonna take over the mysterious shop next door and expand the tables from 2 to 4?
author: Candice B.

description: Tiny, little hip coffee shop without that hipster smugness that so often comes along with cool decor and delicious coffee. This is not a place where you can expect to hang all day (last I checked they don't have wi-fi, but that may have changed). There are only a couple tables and a bench. Hollow is a little magical stop-over - a mini retreat before my long work-day, a place to browse expensive, but delightful gift items made from cast iron, glass, and herbal remedies arranged on wooden shelves like ancient curios, to lick my lips as I contemplate an array of baked goods that could be served in a Redwall novel, and to chat with the good humored staff who labor with love to make the most imminently digestable latte in town. If anyone is reading this, my only suggestion is that your coffees to-go could be a little hotter so that they will linger just a moment longer!
author: Moonbird G.

description:
My ultimate hang out  cafe. I LOVE THIS PLACE. I found it and no one told me about it. Suck it....friends who tell me about cool places!!!!!! Anyways, i love this place. I think I already said that. Well, I was walking along Irving and I run into this place. I pass by it at first, but I decide to walk back and check it out. I walk in and there is a ~30 year old gentleman. I forgot his name, but he is a really chill guy. He even plugged in my iPod into his speakers to listen to my music. They don't have internet, but that's okay because sometimes I feel like talking and hanging not working. I wish them the best. 

What can make this place better are the following:

1) Outdoor seating (helllooooooo....summer is coming) 
2) A bike rack (San Francisco is a bike town...don't forget)

" I am gonna divorce my previous favorite cafe and marry this one."

Best, 

-Al
author: Al A.

description:
YES - YES - YES.I highly recommend this establishment. We happened upon the shop when we were in the neighbourhood to have our Miele vacuum cleaner repaired (another fine business to ck. out on the street -  opposite side). 

They know how to make an excellent espresso and hot chocolate.  The shop is cozy, friendly and delightfully decorated. Locals & newbies are treated like warmly as if family.

Oh yes, they also have a fine collection of Fr. soaps....our new favourite spot to purchase these fine items.
author: Heather M.

description: Whoopie pies will surely lead to the end of my dreams of becoming a International supermodel. Oh well!
author: Sophia C.

description: Prettiest cafe in San Francisco. This cafe itself is like an art. Good pastry line-ups too. Coffees are good, but hot chocolate is not recommended.
author: Nancy H.

description: My daily pit-stop before work. Real Espresso. Real Baristas.
author: Sammy C.

description:
Great tiny place for a relaxing moment not involving long lines of caffeinds waiting for a quick fix. Got a mocha and small scone with the table in the window.

Also enjoyed the artisan housewares for sale.
author: Peter M.

description:
I was sent off to get some coffee from this specific location. Little did I know that when I was told this was an obscure spot did I realize it after I passed it 5 times. Hmmm, peeped in the window to see if it was open, how cute and charming was this place. I walked through the green door, it had little planter boxes outside, no sitting area on the inside or outside and I will explain why after the rest of my encounter. The inside is narrow and rustically dark, very European country side with knick knacks such as garden items, boutique perfumes (ingenious because after you smell each perfume, your nose palate gets cleansed by the surrounding coffee smell), soaps and candles. Think Harry Potter country side store without the actual magic, but this place was in itself magical as it is. 
Now to the things I came here for, what do you think of when you think of "decaf" coffee, flavorless, blah, similar to non alcoholic beer, wtf is the point? The coffee that was made is comparable if not BETTER then blue bottle, I shift you not (yes, I meant to say "shift"). I see that this place is environmentally conscientious as it had a little spot for your cream and sugar, no sugar packets or plastic stirrers and all the items were recycled except for the coffee lids which is understandable. The coffee is made with thought and care, for decaf, it was DELICIOUS, I almost drank it before it got to its intending consumer. I also got a Guinness cupcake, I don't know where they purchase it but someday I'm going to get the recipe, it's moist and delicious and the frosting is cream cheese goodness, not butter cream crap(not a fan). 
Ok, so the reason for no seating inside and or outside is to preserve the quality of the coffee, think about it, no loiters or people waiting impatiently for their coffee while crowded amongst the loiterers, it makes sense. Retain the quality of the coffee and retain the loyal coffee drinkers, this is almost like a hidden gem, too good to talk about yet I have to relay the goodness. Good coffee = repeat patrons
author: Natasha C.

description:
There's something so satisfying about stumbling into a small business run by friendly people. There's something extra satisfying when that very same location has just opened, and you feel like you've *discovered* something. I suppose that's a large part of the appeal of Yelp to me. I remember the thrill of having first post on at least one place on this site. Maybe it's a similar instinct that drives people to leave graffiti on a pristine wall, or to take the time and effort to write "first post" in the comments section of some on line video share sites. Whatever it is, the excitement is palpable, and apparently runs as a crosscurrent throughout humanity. It is with that same excitement that I am writing about Hollow.

Last weekend, walking to Underdog for lunch, we passed a new storefront right next to the hand rolled cigar store, and across from the red brick Chinese seafood emporium. Stopping in for "just a peek" turned into a substantial visit that warmed my heart to the point of being inspired to review after having taken many months off since even logging into this site.

My gf and I enjoyed chatting with the proprietors who were both in the place making espresso drinks, tea, and serving good local pastries. I forget where they were from, but having 2 wheat-free (and one gluten free) pastries was a big plus for me. I liked the macaroon and peanut butter chocolate chip blob. My gf said the maple glazed scone thing was awesome. Both of us are caffeine-phobic, yet the smell of the Ritual coffee upon entrance was enough to inspire us to try it. We both shared a single latte. I was pleasantly buzzed, without any sour stomach aftereffects. While chatting and complementing the coffee, I learned form the barista that Ritual certifies and trains the business that serve their beans. That apparently includes something about how long the shots are pulled, in order to get maximum flavor and minimum bitter. So, sunset district dwellers be advised, you *can* get your officially trained ritual buzz on and not have to suffer the crowds of the mothership store on Valencia! Big points!
author: Alex J.

description: cutest little cafe ever. rustic and charming. they sell the most random of things. the cookies look delicious and coffee is Ritual, my fave!
author: Regina C.

description: My friend and I were out for a stroll on Irving when we spotted this adorable little cafe.  When I say little, I mean LITTLE.  We had her stroller with us, and it fit in the door, but no one could have gotten around it if they tried.  They roast Ritual coffee, which I've been hearing about, and the owner was super nice so I decided to throw caution to the wind and try a cup of coffee after 3pm today.  They only brew espresso drinks, so I went with the Americano.  DELICIOUS!!  Ritual coffee certainly lives up to the hype, and this is the place to get it if you don't want to deal with snobby coffee roasters (which is what I've heard about the location in the Mission).  Parking is on the street, but it's incredibly easy to get parking in that neighborhood.  Not sure if there is outdoor seating in nice weather, but I sure hope so!
author: Cori D.

description: Good morning, fellow yelpers! After a really rough weekend, I was delighted with the Guinness cupcakes and a nice skinny latte. As always, I am a big fan of the small quaint places and I love this place. The service was great, greeted with a warm smile and followed by great treats!
author: carina g.

description:
The owners clearly love good espresso so customers can expect to revel in the fruits of their barrista-astic ways. Bottom line, fine coffee, caring owners, a top-notch experience at a tiny neighborhood coffee joint. 

Guiness-beer chocloate cupcake induced a sugar high I'm likely to remember for some time to come.

Since its unlikely I'll ever live the dream of running such a shop myself, I'll freely dispense some advice: the euro-kitch does create ambience and coziness... but the balance tips slightly towards clutter: lose a few items and/or widen the geographic scope of the offerings. If it was me, I'd say focus on countries/cultures that supply the coffee you so ably serve up; perhaps by toning down the extraneous decor a bit you could add another table or a small counter since part of the joy of this venue is the cozy, local atmo; add one or two different coffee options for the espresso aficionados who might like to try a 'flight' and compare... the husband half of the owner team clearly knows his stuff and, like a vintner, could educate visitors on the differences between beans, roasts, and geographic sources;  add more tea choices; wander past the pastry aisle at Rainbow Foods and include a few of their home-made, healthy, locally-micro-produced products in your spread...they'd complement the nice items you already have.

There is something also pretty cool about the fact they're right next door to a cuban cigar factory. Now, what can we do to create some kind of unprecedented (unnatural?) sybmiosis between these two places?!
author: Michael H.

description:
Love this place!  

It's not only great for coffee and a sweet but also for a unique gift.
author: Kari G.

description: Great lattes! Love the decorations of hearts or leafs to look at when I take that first sip! Total money!
author: Razel F.

description:
SO excited to find this hidden gem. I found the cafe through a website that was featuring coffee spots that served awesome SF coffee, but weren't packed like Ritual/FourBarrel/BlueBottle always are nowadays. 

I came in here after a long stroll through Golden Gate Park, and was pleasantly surprised to be able to spend lots of time looking at all the beautiful things for sale. 
 
I was tempted by all the lovely home-baked goodies she had. Vegans would be happy with the huge selection of desserts here!
I am coming back to get an empanada next time, they looked delicious. 
The owner is extremely pleasant to talk with, and she knows coffee well! She prepared an excellent cappuccino for me, and even put together an ice tea for my friend-even thought it wasn't part of their menu. 
There is also Red Blossom tea, which is definitely my favorite tea in the bay area! 

I hope local residents continue to visit and support this lovely cafe!
author: Alexandra a.

description: I went there today while I was waiting for my laundry to be done and I really liked it. I had a chai tea latte and an anise cookie it was super tasty. They also have a bunch of cool little trinkets for sale that are cool. I would give this place more stars but they were a bit too pricey if only the drinks were a bit bigger. I understand times are tough and you gotta make rent.However I will be going back next time I am doing my laundry!
author: Lauren L.

description: Love the decor & ambiance, but the coffee and food is sub par. I had the vanilla bean latte & I wish they would have drained out all the bits of vanilla so I didn't have to chew them all. It was good, but could have been better. We also had the Spanish chicken empanada which had very little chicken. I would go back, but I wouldn't get anything I had the first time.
author: Amy R.

description: Hollow is a great little coffee spot, quite different than the other local spots and a bit off the busy Irving st. strip  I also discovered that it is a place where you can get Dandelion chocolate.
author: Dennis M.

description: I'd like to see a little tweaking in the layout of this coffee shop.  Part of its charm is the closet size space, so that I will leave alone.  There needs to be a tiny bit of uncluttered counter space by the register to place drinks on, or pehaps sit my purse down while rifling around for cash.  I'm not  really sure if there is a good way to prevent bottle necks, but the milk and sugar at the back make for a little cluster fuck if anyone else is at the register trying to balance their hot drink, while shoving change into their wallet  and waiting for you to fix your. shit and get out of their way.  Well made coffee, though!
author: Lauren M.

description:
This morning I walked 1.5 miles to Hollow and it was worth every step. 

Very friendly atmosphere, lots of cool stuff filling the space and an excellently made latte.
author: Monika V.

description:
Wow, a place with amazing style, integrity and personality... please come in and appriciate the art that is this store- antiques, art and design beautifully combined with perfectly done espresso drinks and high quality artisan sweets. They even have a gluten-free vegan peanut butter chocolate chip cookie which is amazing! You'll have to ask for it because it blends in next to the other amazing goodies.

*they serve Ritual beans

*this review is written by a Blue Bottle lover
author: S...... p.

description: My go to coffee fix. I love love love Hollow and had to re-review now that I've tried the treats also. The oat cake and Guiness Cup Cakes are both incredible. When I'm willing to indulge on weekend mornings, I go there and get a latte or Mocha, one of those two baked goods, and leave with my day off to the perfect start. I also love to support this business since it's owned by residents of the neighborhood. More businesses should still be that way.
author: Shoshana D.

description: Great service and finally amazing STRONG coffee in the inner sunset! Only $2 and absolutely delicious. I heart Hollow.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Great little neighborhood coffee shop.

Definitely worth stopping into if you are in the neighborhood.

Nice owners, amazing coffee/late/espresso
author: Geoff E.

description: Best latte in a 2-mile radius. Maybe more!
author: Mikhail S.

description: Cute little coffeeshop, but I don't know why they can't serve coffee. It's espresso drinks only.
author: Patrick S.

description:
i stumbled across this place, which happens to be only two blocks from my house and now it's my go-to coffee shop. there's a lot of charm in the fact that they only serve espresso drinks and that the place is about the size of a closet. the baristas are always cordial and seem to know their coffee.

i usually go for a latte or an americano, which are always excellent, and worth the price. food-wise, i've only tried the guinness cupcakes, which are great (i love guinness) but a little too small and expensive.
author: Jon D.

description: Tried their americano and oatmeal coffee cake on Saturday, and both were delicious. The decor and ambiance is fun and cute- loved stumbling upon this!
author: Lara M.

description: Charming coffee shop. I tried mocha and it was great n creamy! They have a little antique collectibles for gifting, good selection but a little expensive. Place to have afternoon cup of coffee. I am in love with the cosy charm of the space. Must try than the regular startbucks!
author: Payal B.

description:
In a neighborhood where most coffee shops specialize in tapioca ball drinks this place is seriously refreshing. Hollow serves excellent european style espresso; our americanos were pulled so expertly, just a hint of sweetness, that they didn't need anything added. I really respect a place that doesn't try and do too much, you're much better off doing a few things well, rather than a lot of things poorly. They don't even have drip coffee, and forget about ice blended drinks. The atmosphere is cool too, with reasonably priced home design stuff and some delicious looking treats.
Go to Hollow and find out one more reason why the sunset is the best neighborhood in the city.
author: Lewis A.

description: So inviting from the outside and even cuter inside. Like stores the way I like people!
author: Emm C.

description: The Hollow is a sweet little cafe that has amazing ambiance. It's like sitting in a tiny little cozy cottage or barn, like something you would find down a hidden street in a tiny village in Europe somewhere. The tea was great, they have lots of little gift items that make me want to redecorate my house, and awesome service. The man working behind the counter the day I went in was very friendly and easy to chat with, and made us feel welcome to sit and enjoy. I don't make it to this neighborhood very often, but when I do I will stop here each time. :)
author: Jessica M.

description: Nice coffee and nice employees equals a cool place with nice decorations.
author: Neramitt S.

description: Love, love, love everything about this darling little spot.  Didn't know what it was for a full year, but when I saw the sign proclaiming espresso and gifts I went in.  The owner and the barristas are all beautiful, smart and great with the small talk.  Fabulous coffee, oatmeal cake is best sweet in SF, and I've gotten completely unique and affordable last minute gifts that people love.  You'll be hooked after your first visit...
author: Linda C.

description: So cute you'd want to pinch its little cafe cheeks...this is the place for great coffee in the Sunset.  The decor is stylish in this cafe/shop (mostly shop) and the two 2-tops are a nice place to hang over your Ritual Roasters coffee.  Really good prices and innovative pastries that you won't find just anywhere.  I haven't found a lot of 5-star destinations lately, but this is one of them.
author: Josh M.

description: Seriously mad barista skills, cozy, well-curated interior (apparently one of the owners is an interior designer and the shelves and surfaces are decorated with the artifacts of her livelihood), and excellent nummies (they bring in the most adorable mini-cupcakes, pastries and other goodies from local artisan bakers) add up to a five-star destination.  Don't plan to have breakfast or a meal - the goodies seem to be unpredictable and they flow in at out at various times of the day - but a terrific place to grab a morning latte or while away an afternoon over coffee and snacks.  Weather-permitting you can drag a table and chairs out to the sidewalk too.  I now look forward to tasks that take me to the Sunset so I can swing by Hollow and enjoy one of the best lattes in town.
author: Katy M.

description:
I think this place is great. And the coffee is really good. I've been here a couple times and the espresso was consistently good, which is more than I can say for any other place within a 5 block radius. 
I like that its small and local and that the interior is aesthetically rich. It goes well with a good cup of coffee.
author: Josef S.

description: This cute little spot has pretty good espresso. What won me over was the gluten-free peanut butter chocolate chip cookie. It was pricey for a little thing -- $1.50 -- but that's how it goes in the world of gluten-free treats! I'd come here again. It's a cozy, small space with only two tables and a bench outside. Service is friendly. Decor is pretty rad.
author: Lauren L.

description: Adorable little place tucked away in the Middle Sunset. The inside is TINY, but furnished like rustic European style and they have delicious food. The only reason why it won't get 5 starts is because it serves ONLY espresso, and the food is a tad bit more expensive than I would imagined. However, definitely worth it!
author: Monique K.

description:
I have only been here once but I had a great experience! The couple who own and run the cafe do an excellent job of providing hot beverages and yummy treats. They serve Ritual Coffee and the espresso machine is top notch! The interior is like eye candy. For such a small place, there are tons of decorative elements and it's all for sale! Great place to buy some gifts as well.

Support the local joints and they will support you!
author: James K.

description: Hollow has wonderful decor and neat ideas for pastries, but I'm not quite sure about the wait staff and prices...they seem like a bad trade for being in a hip place.  Guiness cupcake was good and a fascinating idea, but I've had better cupcakes before.  I'm glad I tried it, but I wouldn't go back.
author: Jo S.

description: I've only been here once since it is really out of the way for me, but if you're looking for a great cappuccino in the Sunset, this surely must be THE place to go. I also got a Guinness cupcake as per yelper suggestions and was not disappointed.
author: Lion G.

description: I just moved to SF- and lucky us, we have the lovely Hollow, just around  the corner. I look forward to my daily (almost) latte, served at just the right temperature. Lots of curious bits and bobs to browse while I wait. Lovely staff with very agreeable taste in music. The place smells great! Look- I LOVE it. And the Guinness Cupcakes, congratulations.
author: Barbara N.

description: This tight (literally) neighborhood cafe was a pleasant surprise to discover.  It's one of the most unique businesses I've come across lately. There's a great selection of home decorations & soaps, baked goods, and most importantly, espresso drinks. The quadruple-shot americano ($3) had me buzzin' for hours. Some of the pastries include a cupcake flavored with Guinness beer, earl gray truffles, and cashew scones. Hollow is easy to miss if you don't live in the immediate area, but it's not far from 9th and Irving and definitely worth checking out.
author: Leon R.

description: What a cute little place! I am always amused by the interesting gift selections they have there, although I haven't bought any. I am there for the coffee and they make it good! Good quality Ritual Beans are used in their coffees. Their cookies are good too. The guy, the girl, the owner... everybody is genuinely nice and friendly. Go!
author: Mike S.

description:
My friend and I were walking down Irving Street to the Hardly Strictly Bluegrass festival in GG Park yesterday morning.  We noticed the cigar store next to Hollow (her dad is a cigar fanatic) and at first thought that the open door to Hollow would yield up some 'cuban' cigars.  We walked in to Hollow and were immediately impressed with the eclectic mix of items (great store to find clever, charming, and reasonably priced gifts for friends and family).  Then we both ordered cappuccinos, and time stood still....
We were both in agreement that yesterday morning we experienced the greatest, most delicious, smooth, robust, non-bitter, amazing cappuccino EVER!  My Sunday morning routine used to be to grab a coffee at the Coffee Bean.  Not anymore.  Seven extra blocks are worth coffee nirvana.
author: Jim H.

description:
I've been Hollow several times biking through the neighborhood (for a pick me up)

It's a small charming shop where you can get a great cup of espresso. The times I have gone, William, the owner served me my drink. He is super friendly and willing to have a chat about just about everything. Plus he is a resident of the neighborhood (I just love supporting mom and pop shops) so he was able to recommend several places for lunch to me.

The shop has a lot of interesting nick-knacks to look at (not really me) and a few tables to sit down out. I only wish the shop was a bigger. A giant plus for playing David Bowie the last time I was there.

Hollow definitely has a neighborhood field. Congratulations to the owners.
author: Mateusz S.

description: Excellent espresso, and very nice baristi.  I hope the knick-knacks in the shop are selling well, though, as they take up most of the space that could be used for seating (there are 2 or 3 cramped tables inside).
author: Ari M.

description: I stopped by for a soy latte and two cookies.  Not only was the service excellent and courteous, the portions were just right.  not too crazy big and a reasonable price.
author: Willis W.

description: Great lattes! This cute little "green" cafe definitely stands out from everything else on the block. I'm only 5' tall, but I felt like a giant in there, but I like small, intimate places. =) Will definitely return to try their other items!
author: Michelle C.

description:
C and I have been trying to go to this place since it opened (it closes at 5??) but haven't made it until today. I'd had a chance to peek inside a couple times before (they were also closed president's day) and had been interested by the  kind of second-generation-hippie woo-woo vibe(as opposed to the openly hostile environments of most chic mission coffee houses). Mostly I just needed badly to be able to get a decent cup of coffee in my neighborhood. Its a small space, longer than it is wide (which is nice, i like that) that has just two tables right up front (the front one is like exactly perfect for people watching in my opinion[if thats your thing]). There are a lot of... things, for sale. I agree that it reminds of Paxton Gate; a bunch of things that I either think are really stupid or completely awesome (Holy s---, they sell BATS, C, come look at this they sell bats I'm getting one, we need a bat, its not FOR anything, its... its a bat) that no one actually needs and I don't have the money to get any of this anyway why did I ever even come here... I hate that bat. 

I will say it is a very thoughtfully selected collection of stuff and definitely establishes the P.O.V. for the place (If you have ever been to Vashon Island, WA then you've got a pretty good frame of reference) I will even admit to briefly deciding I needed a pair of salt shakers with tops shaped like animal heads and then C talking me down. Anyway, you've got to walk past all these things to get your coffee.

C ordered a Gibraltar (which is not something I would ever do in a new place like this because what if they don't have the cup and get embarrassed or think I'm an asshole or or???). My anxiety disorder and I ordered a latte. We all decided to share a vanilla cup-cake.

Since we were the only ones there I can't speak much to service except to say that the man and the woman were very professional and welcoming, our drinks were prepared swiftly.

We sat at the table that wasn't the one that was right in front of the window and perfect for people watching. This bugged me but the table we were at was actually still pretty good for window watching and I was probably just being childish.

The coffee was good, the cupcake was good and both had prices that made sense. When we got home I told C I'd definitely be going there again the next time I was home and wanted to go out for a cup of coffee.
author: crumb s.

description: Cutest coffee shop. Ever. I love all their nick nacks!  Their coffee is a little pricy though.
author: Katie M.

description:
this place is quaint. i mean small. tiny.

when i walked in the girl behind the counter was playing the soundtrack to the 1990 motion picture 'Home Alone', and i became instantly at ease.

on a rainy day, this place offers the ideal shelter from the water above-- and there are plenty of trinkets and statues to beckon your imagination.

tea selection is basic, all the things you'd expect from a neighborhood barista are for sale.  very reasonable prices, as well.

so i recommend this place if you're trying to kill time while at the laundromat on the corner, or if you're searching for the perfect hollow to sip some tea.
author: L J.

description: Hands down!  My favorite coffee shop in SF.  I always come with $ in my pocket because I know I'll end up buying something other than coffee here.  Good coffee, awesome plants, great selection of unusual gifts, and pleasant service.  Love it!
author: crystal r.

description: Delicious lattes! So creamy and wonderful! Oh and the little chocolates....... I can't get enough. White green tea and Hazelnut are my favorites. They have amazing smelling candles and soaps for sale too. Whenever I am in the neighborhood, I make sure I stop by for my fix. The owners are super friendly too. Would recommend this place in a heart beat!
author: K W.

description: So happy these guys are my naighborhood espresso shop! Only wish the earth would spin a 180 so sunlite would hit the store. Sigh. I'll settle for now
author: Dakota Wilder S.

description: I stumbled upon this place while wandering around.  I didn't get anything because I had just had coffee, but I liked it so much I took a business card so I'd remember to go back.  I left the city soon after, so I haven't actually consumed anything from there, but it gets five stars from me for looking so interesting and quaint.  I loved all the little soaps and things for sale.  Plus I love Ritual espresso, so I know I'd love it.
author: Bridget S.

description: I really like this coffee shop... very quirky and filled with character.  This is a low key place to get an artisan drink made to high quality standard (Latte Art, good beans, etc).  This place is small and you won't be able to hang out with your laptop and order giant super sized iced drinks (i.e. Starbucks), it is more of a place for quality, not quantity.  Love it!
author: Carlton M.

description: Fantastic little cafe, serving Ritual coffee in the Sunset.  Lots of cute little trinkets and delicious pastries for sale.  No drip coffee, but easily the best source for espresso drinks in the neighborhood.
author: John D.

description: Excellent cappuccino, cozy atmosphere, nice curios inside.  It's nice to have a great coffee place within walking distance in the Inner Sunset, finally!
author: Jessica L.

description: Hollow is seriously like the owners hollowed out a hole-in-the-wall between its neighbors, and that's why I like it. I felt like I was in a comfy, little burrow. The hot chocolate was great, especially with the lemon bar, and everything was served to me!!! They even handled the bill as I sat. I plan on returning as soon as I can.
author: Julian S.

description:
This place is quaint, their peanut butter chocolate chip cookies are divine. It's not in my neighborhood, and I go out of my way to go see them and get an artisan latte -- they use Ritual beans. 

Also, great place to buy adorable gifts!

LOVE IT. Agree that Greg's review below is ridiculous.
author: Laura E.

description: Like it here, could use better lightning at tables. It can be hard to concentrate on reading as the place is small and conversations are hard to ignore. Not much of a variety of sweet treats but what they have is pretty good. Wish it weren't as popular as it is, sorry!
author: brian d.

description: Tiny little shop serves up excellent cappuccino- creamy frothy with just the right amount of bitterness from espresso. Well done! This shop also sells other little things like fancy soaps and rustic decorator items. Tho I'm not too crazy about it...
author: Quynh I.

description: The coffee is fine, and the decor is awesome.  It smells of yummy soaps and coffee.  The sweets look good, but I haven't tried them.  I gave them 3 stars as they don't give you a discount for bringing in your own cup, and they don't fill it to the top.  Therefore, I go elsewhere that fills it to the top, charges less and discounts me for reusing a cup.
author: Melissa M.

description: A wonderful little neighborhood coffee shop. The latte was creamy and well done. The only issue was the flavor was a little weak. I had a gluten free (which typically means taste free) peanut butter chocolate chip cookie that was phenomenal.  The barrista was also very pleasant. This is a really nice little coffee shop that I would certainly go to again.
author: Erik S.

description: Great espresso!!! This small place is like Paxton-Gate and Philz had a love child. Nice strong coffee, really cool gift and antique stuff, and the maple bacon scone/muffins are tasty.
author: Spoke K.

description: I used to like going to Kaleo down the street but now I'll be going to Hollow. It's closer (just a hop and a skip away) and this tiny place is totally gives me the warm fuzzies!!
author: Violet C.

description: I found this place on yelp when trying to pick a good spot to meet my aunt for coffee and it was perfect.  All the cute little stuff/gifts around made the ambiance wonderful, the coffee was delicious, and the service was great.  Only two tables makes it hard for hanging out so make a back up plan in case they're both taken.  We were lucky and hogged one of the tables for about an hour (sorry other patrons!) for a nice visit.
author: Tamsen S.

description: Hell yeah! This place rules. Its like a bluebottle with cool stuff for sale.
author: sebastien r.

description: This storefront was originally a haircut place, I think. When I came back from a Christmas holiday in Los Angeles, it was this coffee place. Is the Sunset gentrifying? Nah! Good lattes.
author: Nicky G.

description: this place makes a mean espresso, not easy to find one this good in this part of town.  holla
author: Josh F.

description: I have walked past this charming little place many times and finally stopped in for an Americano.  The owner (I am assuming/same guy as in the picture) is friendly and helpful.  The Americano was among the best I've had with a thick layer of crema on the top.  And though I did not partake, Hollow has a nice little selection of bakeshop sweets that look every bit as delicious and high quality as the coffee.  Although I worried about the lack of patrons during my time there, I plan to keep going back with the hope that others will too.  This place reminds me of the kind of shop one might find on the tiny streets of the Marais, not on the somewhat tired stretch of Irving between 19th Ave and Andronico's.  But with the opening of Underdog, King of Noodle and now Hollow, I am beginning to wonder if this is a temporary flurry of delightful new additions to my neighborhood or the beginning of something new in the sleepy Sunset.  I am hoping for the latter.
author: Christopher M.

description: This place is the hidden gem of the Sunset. Not only is the coffee good (Ritual Coffee?! And in the 'Set?!), but the merchandise is cool, and the owners are always friendly. Yeah, like others have said it's on the smallish side, but I kinda like it that way.  Makes it feel like you're the first person to discover it...
author: Nate H.

description:
very nice owners.  charming little place.  nice for a conversation or to do a little work.  very good tea, and i hear everything else is good, too.  barista takes a lot of care with your beverage.  will definitely be returning!  nice that the sunset finally has something like this.

please visit!
author: annabel l.

description: Not only is the coffee great here (be careful though, no drip - since they just opened they're only doing espresso drinks right now), but it's exactly the neighborhood spot the inner sunset needs. I would advise people to start going now, and get to know the friendly owner before they get too many customers to be able to know each one personally.
author: Nora O.

description: William, the co-owner (w/ his wife), is easy-going and friendly. This is the perfect place to get a cup of well-made coffee and feel inspired by the surroundings. They carry fun and reasonably priced curios/small home accoutrements. It's a small, but cozy, space. The interiors will relax you. It reminded me of petite curio shoppes in Scandinavia. A real gem - I'm proud to have them in the Sunset.
author: C L.

description: The owner was nice with a real positive energy. My new favorite place.
author: Heather L.

description: Hollow is such a great addition to the neighborhood.  The owners, who as I understand are husband and wife, are both so very friendly; and they prepare the drinks so very well.  I can't order a latte at most cafes, because most cafes burn the milk.  You can't really blame them since so many people ask for their drinks to be "extra hot."  Seems to be the norm.  The point is, Hollow is not most cafes.  The milk is steamed to a perfect temperature and it always looks beautiful.  This is all not to mention the charming, for lack of a better word, "trinkets" that are for sale--from strange bird cages to candle sticks mounted on driftwood; from uniquely crafted coffee and tea mugs to metal, animal-shaped drawer handles.  It's all great stuff, nothing tacky.  The place almost feels as if you're entering the owners' home, which seems to give even the most out of touch customers an overly respectful demeanor.  This all adds up to five stars some how.  Go check out Hollow.
author: Gregory H.
